TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer him to recent reports that homosexuals have been granted permanent residence in Australia on the basis that they have struck up a long lasting relationship with a homosexual partner in this country. I ask: Is it true that 149 homosexuals have been granted permanent residency since 1985? Are there another 110 applicants in the pipeline? Was this policy introduced by Chris Hurford in 1985? Is it true that change of status approvals for homosexual partners are made at a ministerial level rather than at a departmental level? Will the Government have the program stopped until the public has been informed of what is going on and has had a chance to debate it? At the very least, will the Minister make it mandatory for applicants to have an acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) test before permanent residential status is granted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read some of the honourable gentleman's comments, which were based upon newspaper allegations about homosexual intake in our immigration program which were totally incorrect. The suggestion that homosexual couples are coming into Australia as part of a family reunion program is totally inaccurate and total nonsense. What did occur in 1985 under Minister Hurford was that the amendment to section 6a (1) of the Migration Act created a situation where, on the basis of legal advice, an Australian citizen who had entered into a homosexual relationship could challenge legally if an applicant sponsored by him in that situation was declined residential status solely on homosexual grounds.

ANSWER.PARA: Since then, successive Ministers for immigration have personally considered applications from people temporarily here to remain in Australia on the basis of genuine, longstanding, monogamous homosexual relationships. For the information of the honourable member, the provisions of section 6a (1) extend basically to a discretion by the Minister to meet situations outside the broad framework of the Act. For example, an Australian citizen may be ill or need support and someone such as a second or third cousin but not in a direct family relationship might then be prepared to come to Australia to provide that level of assistance. It becomes a matter of ministerial discretion.

I should also point out to the honourable gentleman, in case he believes that there is something secret about this provision, that there is nothing secret at all about it. In fact, this provision is well known to members of the Opposition. I say this in a completely apolitical way. In many of the cases that have come before me I have had representations from honourable members on both sides of the House and from both sides of the Senate. Let me say this to the honourable gentleman, who seems to feel threatened by all of this: we are dealing with a very small group of people, a total of about 50 a year, which is infinitesimal compared with the total immigration program intake. It is certainly not the case, as has been suggested, that the admission of any particular non-resident in this category in any way at all affects any other applicant. In particular, it does not affect, as has been suggested, applicants under the family reunion program. That allegation is also untrue.

There is one other matter that should be brought to the attention of the Parliament, since the honourable member feels that there are some secrets about this. In order to formalise the procedures and make it a departmental responsibility and not the sole responsibility of the Minister, the matter was raised with an Opposition party committee. It was taken to the Opposition committee in about December 1987. All the issues were raised and Minister Young, as he then was, endeavoured to get a general level of support for the proposal which would have made the operation of this aspect of the program simpler and enable it to be handled at a departmental rather than ministerial level.

After discussion, the Opposition decided that it preferred that the decision remain with the Minister. On that basis I continue to carry that responsibility. I hope that satisfies the honourable gentleman. First of all I have gone through the nature of the program. Secondly, it is a program that has been carried out by successive Ministers since the provision of the legal opinion. Thirdly, it is a program which was well known to all members of this Parliament, so the kind of shock and horror that the honourable gentleman has been engaging in--

TALK.START.PARA: —So none of them have been AIDS tested?
—I have raised the question of AIDS testing with my colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health. Subsequently that has become a matter for discussion and review.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister inform the House of the reaction to his proposals for strengthening government schools in Australia?

We are trying to adopt a co-operative model which would allow us, in conjunction with State governments, to assist in ensuring that the public education system is as well equipped as possible to deal with the daunting tasks that confront it as it tries to prepare our young people not only for life but for a life of work.

I have a letter here from Ross Lightfoot who is the member for Murchison Eyre in the Western Australian Parliament. —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is it fair that thrifty Australians who provide for their retirement by making savings out of their after-tax income should be subjected to the same assets test, or any assets test at all, as those who retire with a similar amount of savings saved through tax sheltered superannuation schemes?

In regard to the whole area of the assets test, fortunately, this country has been through the exhibition by the Opposition of its refusal to face up in any way to what had purported to be the policy enunciated by the Leader of the Opposition on a number of occasions, that is, that in using this country's scarce resources, those resources should be targeted towards those most in need and that it was an obscenity that the community was paying pensions to people with very substantial assets. However, let me allow myself the luxury of saying, in conclusion, that I assert with confidence that, by the time the Treasurer has resumed his seat after delivering that statement on behalf of the Government, the people of Australia will have a great degree of confidence that this Government has provided the best possible treatment of the whole question of superannuation. TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the House of the current situation concerning Australian aid to Ethiopia? Have there been recent reports misrepresenting Australia's position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press reports referred to and, in particular, some reports of comments made by the honourable member for Mayo. Several of the points attributable to him are not correct. The Government's policy is to direct Australian emergency aid in Ethiopia to those in need, based on the latest available information from the United Nations and other agencies. Each time we consider an emergency aid package for Ethiopia an effort is made to determine who and where the needy are. There are ongoing reviews to find the best way of channelling emergency aid for Ethiopia. As a result of this the level of aid directed through rebel held areas has altered over a period. So far this financial year more than $2.8m has been directed to rebel held areas of Eritrea and Tigre. However, there are still people in need on both government and rebel sides. With the recent escalation in fighting, the rebels have gained more territory and therefore have a responsibility to feed more people. Obviously, the Australian Government will take account of this factor when considering further emergency aid to Ethiopia.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, our basic concern is to ensure that Australian emergency assistance gets to those in need. The Government rejects claims that our aid is not getting to those in need. The Government views the situation in Ethiopia extremely seriously and has taken up the matter with representatives of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics both in Canberra and in Moscow. We are staying in close contact with the United Nations and other aid donors to Ethiopia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ANTARCTICA: VISITS BY ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY SHIPS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence to his answer to my question on notice No. 759, when he informed me that only one Royal Australian Navy ship had visited the Antarctic region between 1982 and 1987, that that ship had only two sailing days within the region and that there are no RAN ships with ice strengthened capacity. Given that Australia lays claim to a significant part of Antarctica, what does the Minister intend to do to upgrade Australia's capacity to underpin those international claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing immediately. I think the honourable member would be aware that there are fairly strict views in regard to the militarisation of Antarctica-views that are shared not only by the powers that have territory there that is, in some way, acknowledged but also by those who would like to have their claims acknowledged. I think that, were we to make a regular habit of military activity there, some of those who have an objection might see us as, in some way, offending the regime in operation there. As far as I am aware-I cannot fully recall the details of it-another Minister has under consideration at the moment getting our own research vessel with some icebreaking capacity, which will enable us to uphold our effort in an area that constitutes the main basis for our continuing claim in Antarctica; that is, our research effort.

ANSWER.PARA: From all the advice that has been given to me, the question of whether or not our claims will be seen as valid is not going to be based on the question of whether or not we are prepared to fight anyone down there but whether or not we are prepared to utilise the territory that we have claimed for research purposes. So I do not believe we have a defence problem down there. We may, at some point of time, develop a defence problem to our north. I think that is a more realistic likelihood. I would think that, as far as my Department is concerned, we have the appropriate focus at the moment and the question of the defence of our claims really rests with other Ministers who are concerned with the administration of Antarctica.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE: CAREER OPPORTUNITIES FOR WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel concerns the options open to women who wish to pursue a defence career. Can the Minister tell the House what advances are being made in the employment of women in the Australian Defence Force and in expanding their career opportunities within the Services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must thank those in the Opposition for their great interest in this area and I thank the honourable member for Forde for her question and for her strong and consistent interest in the Defence Force as well as in women's issues. I am sure that members of the Opposition, as are members of the Government, are very pleased to note that considerable progress is being made in the employment of women in the Australian Defence Force. Women currently make up 9.1 per cent of the Australian Defence Force, a 50 per cent proportional increase in the last four years. Twenty-two thousand places in the three Services are now open to women. We regard this matter as very serious; not as a joke, as obviously the Opposition does. Of these 22,000 places, 6,000 are in non-traditional technical areas. On 30 June, at the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base at Pearce near Perth, the first woman pilot will graduate. I am delighted about this, but it is not enough just to get women into the Services; we must ensure that they have an attractive career structure. The Air Force has identified 18 pilot positions with the VIP fleet and two instructor pilot positions as open to women in competition with men; so a woman pilot in the RAAF will have a varied and rewarding long-term career available to her.

ANSWER.PARA: Also in terms of our commitment to women in the Defence Force, I am holding a meeting in Canberra with women of different ranks in the three Services to discuss with them their career opportunities. The Government is committed not only to opening up the numbers of women in the Defence Force but also, I think more importantly at this stage, to ensuring that they have an appropriate career structure. This Government is committed to improving opportunities for women in all areas. We do not believe we would be fulfilling our obligations to the people of Australia if we continued, as in the past, to limit opportunities for a career in the Defence Force solely to men.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the wage claims being made by unions in a number of industries for a 6 per cent or higher increase to apply during the next financial year. Can the Minister advise the House what the Government's attitude is to these claims, and, further, can he indicate whether the Government has received a claim for such an increase from Government employees and, if so, what its response has been?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of claims for wage increases that have been made by unions in various industries. In the metals industry and in the areas of building, airlines, paint, the waterfront and various public services, claims have been made for a general increase of 6 per cent plus more for employees who are engaged in restructuring or similar exercises. Those claims, as is well known, have been encouraged by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) as part of the pre-national wage case manoeuvring. The national wage case will come on some time in June at a date to be determined at or after the national wage conference on 7 June.

ANSWER.PARA: The Confederation of Australian Industry has also been engaged in pre-case manoeuvring. It has lodged a claim for effectively removing the first tier of the present two-tier system, so that, if it had its way, under the new system wage increases could be possible only under what is now the second tier. All of these pre-case manoeuvrings are perhaps understandable in the sense that this year, as distinct from previous reviews, there is no obvious wage claim that can be made by the ACTU stemming from the current system, and we are in a unique situation.

As the nation's major employer, the Commonwealth has also been served with a claim for a general wage increase of 6 per cent plus further possible amounts. The Government has discussed that claim with the relevant unions and told them that it is not prepared to discuss details of the claim until after the national wage case has been decided. The Government told the unions, as it has told the ACTU, that it will be supporting in the national wage case an outcome that will enable, in general, real wages to be maintained in 1988-89. The Government has made the point to the ACTU and its wages policy committee and also to the Public Service unions that any increase beyond that would be unacceptable on the grounds that it would increase the gap between wage increases in this country and wage increases in our major trading partners.

I recommend to other employers in the country who have been faced with these wage claims that they adopt a similar approach to that adopted by the Commonwealth in relation to their own employees-that is, that there is nothing wrong with discussing the wage fixing principles to apply in the next system, but they should not agree to any increase until the national wage case is decided and the Commission has laid down what the principles are to be, otherwise those employers could well find themselves committed to a level or type of wage increase outside the national wage fixing principles. I do not think they would particularly want to do that.

I also recommend to the unions that they do not pursue their claims with industrial action. They are bound by the no extra claims commitment they they made in respect of the present system until this system is replaced by the next system. They should know that and should not take industrial action which would be in breach of that commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to recent tax law changes which have been designed to stop the abuses of superannuation tax concessions by the use of certain variable and other types of annuities. I note that those changes are to come into effect on 23 June this year. However, the Australian Taxation Office has failed to provide guidelines for the interpretation of these changes and the extent to which similar types of annuities remain as legitimate investments under the superannuation laws. Can the Treasurer give an assurance that this area will be addressed by the Commissioner of Taxation shortly so that any potential hardship suffered by retirees can be avoided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, as you are probably aware, before this Government changed the taxation treatment of superannuation in 1983, there had been no changes in the superannuation laws of this country for 60 years. In 1983, the Government established a tax upon lump sums and, at the same time, established the vehicles for the preservation of vested superannuation benefits so that employees with superannuation who were leaving employment did not have to cash their superannuation out but could roll it over into one of these bodies, namely, an approved deposit fund. At the same time as we established those mechanisms, we also provided a basis for more closely equating the tax treatment of superannuation lump sums with superannuation pensions. We opened up the opportunities for the growth and development of an Australian annuity business. That business is, of course, growing, and growing rather rapidly. But there have been some attempts by various groups to exploit for tax minimisation reasons the annuity opportunities provided by legislation. The Government has sought to deal with that.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not certain about the extent to which those changes may bear upon the legitimate interests of a superannuant with an annuity. I will put the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's question under examination. First of all, the Deputy might let me know in what specific way he thinks there is a problem. If he can be specific about it, I will direct that to the Commissioner's attention to see whether in fact the existing arrangements are such that they do not threaten the annuity of any genuine superannuant.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Transport and Communications Support concerns plans to increase the use of Melbourne's international airport. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of this report. I can confirm that the new Qantas schedule represents a significant enhancement of services to and from Melbourne.
—That is not right. A flight to London is now three hours longer and one stop flights have been abolished.
—Order!
—There is no direct flight to Tokyo.
—Order!

—I am sure a lot of people would be happy to put up with that three-hour wait if only they could travel to London too. On 16 May, Qantas announced a major new schedule pattern which will introduce a daily non-stop flight from Melbourne to Singapore. ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member has pressed in his discussions the importance of direct Melbourne to Tokyo flights. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The serious implications for cabinet government flowing from the Prime Minister's new definition of ministerial responsibility.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Sunday I issued a news release in which I drew attention to the way in which the handling of the privatisation issue within the Government had gone from being high farce to a total shambles. I reminded the Australian public, as I do the Parliament this afternoon, that over the last week the total chaos, the drift and the indecision, and the total incapacity of the Government to take a decision on this issue had scaled new heights of government irresponsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members want any demonstration of the way in which the Government handled the privatisation issue, the weakness and ineptitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the inability of the Prime Minister to drag his Party to a decision, let alone the decision that he wants, they will find it illustrated on today's The World Today program when Mr Jim Leslie, the Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd, was asked to talk about the $131m operating profit that Qantas had earned in the past year. The announcer said:

The healthy result hides a worrying rise in the company's debt ratio, which is now approaching 80 per cent. At a news conference Mr Leslie had this to say: `Well I think that when it gets above 65 per cent equity debt, to 35 per cent equity, I regard that as getting too high.'

TALK.START.PARA: —He is wrong.

—The honourable member for Calwell says he is wrong-this economic genius who is a mate of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), the Minister who will not keep quiet. The Chairman of Qantas was saying to the Government and to the Prime Minister, `Will you please stop allowing Qantas to bleed to death? Will you please, as Prime Minister of this country, make a decision and decide whether you are going to sustain us out of the Budget or are going to do the sane and sensible thing and allow Qantas to be privatised?'.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Prime Minister's response? His response is not to say, `Yes, Mr Leslie, that is a serious matter and we will address it and make a sensible decision. After 12 months of drift and indecision, after 12 months of Ministers saying what they want to do and backbenchers saying what they want to do, we will finally make up our mind; I will finally drag this rabble that sits behind me to a decision'. No, he does not say that at all. He comes into this Parliament and redefines the doctrine of ministerial responsibility. By far the most revealing aspect of yesterday's exercise in Question Time was not the floundering of the Minister for Administrative Services, whose blue singlet Labor credentials are infinitely better than those of the man who leads his Party, but the Prime Minister's redefining of the doctrine of ministerial responsibility. Yesterday the Prime Minister gave up the ghost on trying to control his Cabinet on the issue. He gave up the ghost on trying to control the Australian Labor Party on the issue. Instead of knocking together the heads of those who destabilised Cabinet government, he decided he would change the rules.

If anybody imagines that that is some fanciful claim by the Opposition, some Westminster abstraction or something dragged from Erskine May's Parliamentary Practice in the dust of the library, let me read from the Cabinet handbook circulated by the Prime Minister in 1988 to all Cabinet Ministers, including the Minister for Administrative Services. This is what it has to say under the heading `Collective responsibility':
Ministers should not make public statements or comment on policy proposals which they are bringing or which are to be brought to Cabinet.
It goes on to say:

Promotion in public of a particular line may pre-empt Cabinet deliberations. Identification of individual Ministers with particular views tends to call into question the collective basis of agreed outcomes. Each portfolio Minister is responsible for direction and public presentation of policy and other Ministers should avoid separate policy stances becoming matters of public debate.

They are not my words; they are not the words of some abstract commentator in the gallery; they are the words of the Prime Minister's own Cabinet handbook. Where is that handbook left after yesterday's declaration? Where is ministerial responsibility? It is in the `too hard' basket. The truth of the matter is that the Prime Minister has lost control not only of his Party but also of his Cabinet on the issue of privatisation. In the words of the Australian Financial Review this morning, he is left humiliated by his friends and his enemies on this issue. For 12 months the Prime Minister's nose has been rubbed in the dirt by a succession of left wing Ministers and union power bosses on this issue.

There is only one person to blame for this. It is not the Minister for Administrative Services. It is not Simon Crean. It is not Senator Walsh. It is not the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). It is the Prime Minister himself. He is the person who honed the rhetorical bullets that are now being hurled at him. He is the person who two years ago attacked the Liberal Party of Australia for supporting privatisation. He is the person who, in concert with his Treasurer (Mr Keating), has run dead on this issue. The Treasurer has counted the heads in Caucus on privatisation. We do not see him raising his head. He knows where the numbers are. He knows that privatisation is dead and he knows, like the undertaker he is, that he ought to go to the funeral and he ought not try to resurrect the carcass, which the Prime Minister is trying to do.

The person responsible for this chaos and mess, and for the fact that some of the great public enterprises of this country are bleeding to death, is none other than the Prime Minister himself. Two years ago he embarked upon the most hysterical, dishonest and shameful campaign that we have heard for years against the privatisation policies of the Liberal Party as enunciated then. He likened them to burning down the gum tree. He said that they were economic vandalism. He said that they were irresponsible. He said that the Australian Labor Party would rather die than surrender its opposition to privatisation.

Miraculously, after the election he, like anybody treading the Damascus path, cast aside all of that. He comes into this Parliament and he goes to the councils of his own Party and says, `I have suddenly realised that privatisation is a great idea. We can no longer afford to put $600m into Qantas. We cannot afford to put $400m into Australian Airlines. We cannot afford to put billions of dollars into these public enterprises. We have to privatise them. We have to sell them off. We have to flog them off to the Australian public. That dreadful thing that we said the Liberal Party wanted to do a couple of years ago, that criminal commitment that the Liberal Party had a couple of years ago to privatise these bodies, we suddenly realise, was not a criminal commitment after all; it was sound national economic policy'.

The pathetic thing about the Prime Minister is that, for the life of him, he cannot understand why, having taught these bad habits, having honed the rhetorical bullets a couple of years ago, they are being flung back at him. He says, `It is not fair. We ought to have an open debate'. It is not an open debate; it is a rout of the Prime Minister on something on which he has been shamefully humiliated by his own Party. The ultimate in the humiliation is not to be found so much in the declaration by Simon Crean-made, appropriately enough, last week-that privatisation was dead, in the meek acceptance on the same day by Senator Evans that it was dead, in the pathetic attempt the following day by the Prime Minister to breath life back into the body, or in the Minister for Administrative Services coming in with a good old Warilla rabbit killer and saying, `It is well and truly dead and we have to administer the last rites at the National Conference'. The really pathetic thing was the sight of this Prime Minister yesterday, in answer to my question, not trying to drag his Cabinet back into some semblance of unity and cohesion.

How on earth can the Government expect the business community to take it seriously when the Minister for Administrative Services says, `It is dead'; Senator Evans says, `It might be'; Crean says, `It really is'; the Prime Minister says, `I hope it is not'; the Treasurer says, `It ought not to be'; and Senator Button says, `Keating is not talking on behalf of the Government when he says that it ought not to be dead.'? How on earth does the Government expect the business community, the people of Australia and the employees of these enterprises to take it seriously when it serves up that nonsense?

Instead of the Prime Minister getting up and saying to his Ministers, `This is how it is going to be', like any leader who had respect and authority would do in such a situation, what did he do? He threw up his arms in horror and said, `Madam Speaker, I can no longer control them. So rather than trying to control them, I'll change the rules. I will amend in Question Time the decades old doctrine of ministerial responsibility'. I read that out from that handbook. Those words are not the words of Howard, the Liberal Party or the National Party of Australia; they are the words of Hawke's own handbook and the guidelines were given to all his Ministers. There is no way the Prime Minister can welsh on them without welshing on the principle of ministerial responsibility. What the Prime Minister has been found wanting on is a capacity to demand of his Ministers the degree of unity and cohesion that ought to be demanded.

What has happened on this issue sends into pale pink insignificance any debate that occurs on our side of the Parliament on any issue at all. I ought to say to the Prime Minister: Do not let us ever hear you, having presided over a shambles of ministerial responsibility, ever talking about debate on policy issues within the Liberal and National parties. From now on the doctrine from this Prime Minister will be a very simple one: no matter what the issue is, no matter who the Minister is, no matter how serious the issue is and no matter how long the debate has gone on, a Cabinet Minister-not just a member of the Ministry; our mate from Warilla, the Minister for Administrative Services, is a Cabinet Minister-can say whatever he likes, as often as he likes, as publicly as he likes on any issue that he likes but, provided the Cabinet has not taken a final decision on it, it is perfectly in order for him to do so. That reduces the doctrine of ministerial responsibility to an absolute shambles. It has all happened because we have a weak Prime Minister who does not have the guts to pull his Ministers into line. It is as simple as that. If he had authority, respect, power and capacity on this issue, he would pull them into line.

The Treasurer knew what he was about. He has not had his head up on this issue. He has been well and truly in the bunker on privatisation. He has trotted out the occasional word about how it is probably a good idea. He likes to brighten up his economic credentials every so often so that everybody in the business community knows that when the chips are down he will put up his hand for privatisation, but if one thinks that he will risk any party standing on the issue, one has another think coming. He has counted the heads on this issue. He knows that the Minister for Administrative Services is right. That is a good combination, the Treasurer and the Minister for Administrative Services, is it not? Perhaps it is the new ticket. He knows that he is right-that Crean, the Minister for Administrative Services and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) have the numbers on privatisation and that the Prime Minister has been done like a dinner on this issue.

I do not think that even the Treasurer imagined that when it came to the crunch the Prime Minister would be prepared to sacrifice what is one of the cornerstones of cohesive and stable government in this country, and that is the principle of ministerial responsibility. Unfortunately, he was wrong and we are all wrong. What really emerges as the great casualty from this debate is something even worse than the reputation of the Prime Minister; that is, the doctrine of ministerial responsibility has been changed permanently by this Prime Minister. It has been changed for the worse and it has been changed for the worse because he does not have the guts and strength of courage to stand up to the rabble behind him and tell them what is the right thing on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We searched through the speech made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to find the rationale for the Opposition bringing forward this matter of public importance at this stage and we found it in one sentence. The reason that the Leader of the Opposition has raised this matter of public importance can be found in his sentence, `Whatever is happening on our side of the House pales into insignificance in comparison with what is happening on the other side of the House'. If one allows the normal amount of exaggeration that everybody defending a case makes on either side of the House, one gets the real reason why the Leader of the Opposition has brought forward this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been having a debate on privatisation, in case the Leader of the Opposition has not noticed, set by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the Australian Labor Party for the last nine months. The Prime Minister called for a debate on privatisation in the Labor Party and in the community. From the outset of that debate, Cabinet Ministers have been commenting on it; they have been commenting on one side or other of the debate for the last nine months. However, the Leader of the Opposition has brought this matter in here nine months later as a matter of Cabinet responsibility. Why has the Leader of the Opposition done this? Because he needs a smokescreen. He needs a smokescreen to protect him from the barrage of criticism he daily receives from the Press not only for weakening the leadership and standing of the Liberal and National parties in this Parliament by his own failures but also for starting to challenge the fabric of an effective democracy in this country. We will have more to say about that when we look at his weak leadership on issues such as the motion that will ultimately be moved in this place on Aboriginal matters and on the question of the Opposition's stance in the referendum campaign which is coming forward. We will discuss that a little later.

It is necessary to dismiss immediately what little effort the Leader of the Opposition has made at putting substance into his nine months late remarks on the question of Cabinet solidarity. As far as the Prime Minister is concerned, the question of Cabinet solidarity is quite clear: when a decision is made by Cabinet, Cabinet Ministers are bound by it. That has been the situation for the five years the Labor Party has been in office. Frequently there is debate inside the Labor Party, in Caucus and in the Cabinet room and elsewhere. Frequently, as I have said, there have been disagreements among Ministers. The point is that when a decision is made by Cabinet all dispute ceases. The Minister to whom the Leader of the Opposition was referring was at one stage a victim of that process. He found himself unable to take Cabinet responsibility on the question of uranium. As a result the Prime Minister placed that Minister outside the Cabinet for a period. So it is clear that the Prime Minister, when Cabinet rules are offended, is prepared to act to ensure that Cabinet solidarity is upheld.

I think we can dismiss immediately what little substance there is to the complaint made by the Leader of the Opposition. There has been no decision reached by Cabinet on the question of privatisation. Privatisation has been a matter of open debate among Cabinet Ministers inside the Party for nine months-as the Prime Minister asked for it to be nine months ago. So the situation now is no different from the situation nine months ago, except in one area. In the nine months since the last election the current Leader of the Opposition daily has given evidence of his inability to control and direct the Opposition parties. What he permits to develop is the politics of the lowest common denominator in the Opposition parties, even if it involves his repeated public humiliation. What greater public humiliation could one hope for than that demonstration the other night after the Leader of the Opposition encouraged the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to go forward to prepare a bipartisan motion for us to move-as we move into our new Parliament House-on a simple matter of acknowledging an historical fact of whether or not the Aborigines occupied this land before most of our ancestors got here. The Leader of the Opposition encouraged the Minister to go down that road. Along with the shadow Aboriginal affairs spokesman, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), the Leader of the Opposition took it to the shadow Cabinet and was comprehensively and typically rolled. He was humiliatingly rolled and the honourable member for Braddon then felt free to come forward into the public arena and say that the shadow Cabinet had effectively rolled his position. Was the honourable member for Braddon thrown out of the shadow Cabinet for announcing a position that the Leader of the Opposition did not want announced then? No, he was carpeted but he was not thrown out of the shadow Cabinet.

Was the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) thrown out of shadow Cabinet when he expressed his disagreement with the Leader of the Opposition on the referendum question? No, the honourable member for North Sydney was not thrown out of the shadow Cabinet for doing that. The honourable member remains in the shadow Cabinet, but he is there humiliated. We very rarely agree with the honourable member for North Sydney on anything, but we have to admire his courage. He is a legal man of some standing. He has come into this place, where he earns about one-tenth of what he could earn outside, basically because he has a few views on life and on the legal proprieties and what one is about when one is in public life, which is improving the quality of Australian life overall. We do not agree with his views but he does have a few views on that matter. When it comes down to a question of whether or not he wants to publicly support trial by jury, whether or not he wants to publicly support recognition by the Commonwealth of local government, whether or not he wants to publicly support freedom of religion, the honourable member for North Sydney is told to shut his mouth. The honourable member did not, as I recollect-I could be wrong but the division lists appear to support my belief-vote for what he was ultimately bound into by the Leader of the Opposition. He may well have had an excuse not to be here at that time; but whatever it was-

TALK.START.PARA: —He was overseas.

—I accept that. I am glad he was overseas because he was not, therefore, obliged to accept the humiliation that the Leader of the Opposition was obliged to accept as he sat in this chamber and voted against the proposition he had written to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to ask him to place before the public in a referendum; what is more, a proposition that sat in the Liberal Party platform at the last election, namely, that local government ought to be given appropriate recognition in the Constitution. This is the leadership offered by the Leader of the Opposition to the people of Australia as an example of not only how he wishes to run a Cabinet but how he wishes to run a government.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the referendum campaigns as they will come forward, that weakness in his leadership will, in the end, impact on the quality of democracy in this country because the propositions that are being put forward are manifestly not advantaging this side of the House. Despite desperate efforts to try to secure some sort of interpretation that they are, they are manifestly not advantaging this side of the House. They represent a bare minimum effort to bring Australians up to a consideration of what the founding fathers always intended be the way in which our Constitution should operate; that is, it should be a living document; it should be a document capable of changing with the times; it should be a document capable of reflecting the points of agreement that there are in the Australian community at any point of time and, in this case, the right that every vote have the same value, the right to trial by jury, the right of freedom of religion. These are not difficult constitutional questions. These are questions of basic human rights on which every side can agree; but the Government is not getting bipartisan support from the Liberal and National parties on these matters, even though it has a right to expect support on at least some of them, given past statements, because the Leader of the Opposition cannot lead. He can only interpret the lowest common denominator. He can get together what is the basic thing on which the Liberal and National parties will be united in disagreement in the majority, and try to carry that.

It does not matter what happens to the principal people in his Party along the way; he will trample them. The difference between that situation and the matter that is being considered here today and the reasons why it is being considered here today is that all that I have said in the last seven minutes is not some new public expose. Every comment that I have made is not some original thought that has penetrated my head and I have managed to get up here and spout it out. Everything that I have said has been the daily fare of the editorials and leader-writers of this country over the last three or four weeks. The reason why we have to have a smokescreen is that, in some degree of desperation, the Leader of the Opposition has to throw this stuff up in the vain hope that, somehow or other, up in the Press gallery-there have not been many of the Press here listening to this debate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look now.

—I have two fewer than the Leader of the Opposition. They have not been listening to him so his smokescreen will not work. His leadership is now a matter of desperation inside the Liberal Party; hence we get letters such as that from Lightfoot, a Liberal Party member from Western Australia, written only a month ago to John Elliott, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: May I congratulate you on your recent advocacy of a Consumption Tax. You are John, totally and unquestionably right. Unfortunately it was not sold properly in its embryonic concept to the public. I am reassured that you have the conviction necessary to maintain (and win!) the only major form of taxation reform that would allow a significant reduction in corporate and personal income tax.
He goes on to say that regrettably he will be in the United States of America so he will not be able to attend a fundraising function in Perth at the time. The letter continues:
I could not concede that the wider public appreciates the hollow chested, limp wristed mixture of wet Liberal/socialism that some of our leaders offer, and with some alacrity, espouse.
You are unquestionably a natural leader, and I regret that there has not been a more positive effort to assist you into Federal politics and to guarantee you a prominent front bench position.
I would earnestly hope that the conservative public use whatever muscle is necessary to open up and facilitate that position for you.
May I offer my regrets and apologise again for missing you on your pending Perth visit to Western Australia.
Lightfoot is a member of the State Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a lightweight!

—He is a lightweight; I do not dispute that, but he represents a substantial view within the Liberal Party about the leadership that is being offered at the moment, which is no leadership. The Party has no leadership on any issue, whether on the question of a decent resolution of the problems of Aborigines or on the question of the referendums. Mr Lightfoot asks here whether the business community continues to have confidence in this Government. The last time a section of the business community had a view to express to parliament, which was on the question of private ownership, business community leaders could go into the office of the Leader of the Opposition and put forward a reasonable position to him. He did not say, `I will take this and consider it; I will go back to the party forum and think about this further', or, `I have a few doubts about your position; I am not sure that I agree with you on these matters. I think there is an insufficient degree of liberality in media ownership'. That was not his response to them. He said, `I agree with you. I will take that matter to my shadow Cabinet and into the party room and we will agree with your position on that. You do not have to worry; the Government can go ahead and prepare legislation'.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do honourable members think we prepared that legislation? Because we like getting knocked over in the Senate but we think it is a terrific idea to keep the Senate debating these matters? We proposed that legislation because we understood that some exercise of leadership was going on inside the Liberal Party such as we had not seen for some considerable time. Far be it from us, in an attempt to improve the quality of government in this country, to allow such an excellent moment to slip by without introducing a useful reform, so we proceeded to do it. What happened? This man, who comes into this place and tells us that the Prime Minister does not know how to run Cabinet Government and does not know how to offer leadership, collapsed like a pack of cards in the face of the opposition of his intellectually massive front bench-fell before the mighty front bench of the Liberal Party. It was the lowest common denominator again-after about half a dozen meetings in the space of about 24 hours flat, the Leader of the Opposition cobbled together a ridiculous policy, came into this House and presented it as leadership.

We have seen from the Leader of the Opposition a mockery of political leadership in this country over the last two or three months. He seeks to conceal that mockery of leadership by this ridiculous little effort of coming in here and telling us that we do not know a thing about Cabinet Government because a Minister who is not bound by any Cabinet decisions has decided to express a view, as he and all other Ministers and members of the Labor Party were invited to do at the time the Prime Minister called for a debate inside the Labor Party-not with the Cabinet excluded from it-and in the general public on the issue of private ownership. It is pathetic and sad that the Leader of the Opposition has come down to this position. It is not to our advantage or the advantage of the country that this country should be possessed of a weak Opposition, but that is the situation we confront and we will all pay the penalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sad and bereft of principle and propriety that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has found it necessary to come in here today and seek to blame the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for the failings of his own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). What this is really about is two main criteria. The first is that yet again there is a sense of deja vu. We are back to the days of Whitlam, the day where the splits of Caucus, the internal fights, were spread amongst the newspapers of Australia; when Cabinet Ministers, having failed in Cabinet battles, took them into the Caucus room and then took them to the public. We are seeing yet again the crumbling of Labor in government-the total ineptitude and incompetence of Labor to reach positive decisions to give people the leadership that the principle and doctrine of ministerial responsibility is all about, but instead to present to them a divided, indecisive and indeterminate face.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the more sinister element is the incompetence of the Prime Minister and his lack of leadership which have led to this situation. This is shades of what happened to Australia in the days of Whitlam. It is shades of what happens when Labor takes over. Progressively we see the factions pull the team apart. As this is happening, men like the present Prime Minister pretend that everything is okay. They come out and say, `It is all a matter of honest democratic debate'. The Leader of the House said that it is all a matter of trying to encourage debate inside the Australian Labor Party. What absolute rubbish. That is not what it is about. It is purely and simply about the Prime Minister not having the numbers.

There is no question that the Prime Minister does not have the numbers, not just on the privatisation issue, and I will have a bit more to say on that in a moment, but on other issues. But the reality is that in the first instance we are seeing a return to the divisions, the ineptitude and the incompetence in policy direction that were set down under the Whitlam Government. Yet again, we find Prime Minister Hawke following in the fashion of Whitlam. Anybody who thinks that this is a different colour Labor Party really ought to have his head examined because it is not. Inevitably, we find that under Labor a Prime Minister is driven by factions and, in this instance, the Left has taken over. That is the second part of what I think this debate is about. The sad part about this matter is that not only is the Prime Minister without leadership and competence but also the Left is really taking over this debate as it is on each of the other major issues that will come before the Labor Party Conference.

I was amazed that the Leader of the House had the cheek to talk about uranium and say that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) was strongly disciplined and was actually told to get out of Cabinet. That is a brilliant way to exercise ministerial responsibility. The Prime Minister says, `Tut, tut' and grabs him by the finger. The Prime Minister does not kick him out of the Ministry. He says, `Oh, you are a naughty boy. You are going to get the same money but we are going to put you out of Cabinet. You can come in here for significant discussions'.

The reality is that there is no ministerial discipline under Hawke. There is no ministerial propriety when Ministers are prepared and able-as the Prime Minister told us all in the Parliament yesterday they can-to go out and talk about what they will until Cabinet policy is established. That is not what the doctrine of ministerial responsibility is about. I could quote any number of authorities-from Quick and Garran, through to Pettifer and the House of Lords-which have laid down the Westminster system of politics which we pursue here.

My colleague the Leader of the Opposition said that we do not have to refer to precedents; we can look at the doctrine that was laid down by the Prime Minister. The Cabinet handbook says it all. The reality is that yesterday the Prime Minister did not acknowledge that there is free and open debate or that there should properly be within the ranks of the Labor Party and the community a re-examination of the arguments around privatisation. The Leader of the House said it all. This debate has been going on for nine months. Why cannot honourable members opposite come to a decision? Nine months and they still have not taken a decision. Nine months and they want free and open debate. We heard from the Minister for Administrative Services today. Was he free to come out and tell us what it is all about? Mind you, that did not deter him out on the front steps of Parliament House this morning.

But he and Simon Crean know that privatisation is dead. Privatisation is dead not because there has been a proper consideration of the funding needs of Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank, Australian National, the Australian National Line or any of the other public instrumentalities that all of us in this place know are starved of finance, but because the Left has the numbers. The Prime Minister is yet again showing that he is unable to give leadership to Australia. In exactly the same way as Gough Whitlam before him, we are finding that this Prime Minister too has feet of clay.

I want to talk on three other issues. I am quite fascinated that the Leader of the House spoke not just on privatisation. He also spoke about Aborigines. We want to remember that it was the Prime Minister, without telling his Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who went out and said there was going to be a compact among the Australian people and that that compact was going to be entered into between his Government and the Aboriginal people. We know how the Prime Minister misled them, how he pretended that in some way they were going to be better off as a result of his giving them some sort of agreement. It was not an agreement that would give them better health conditions, that would in any way address their unemployment problems or that would provide them with better housing. All it would give them was words. However, yet again, the Prime Minister did not have the numbers. Just as was the case with privatisation the Prime Minister knows that what has happened with Aboriginal affairs is yet again a result of divisions within the Australian Labor Party. A few days after the Prime Minister's announcement, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs said that he did not know anything about it. Why should he? After all, he was only the Minister responsible.

We also have the question of uranium. Apart from the fact that the Minister for Administrative Services was given a bit of a rap on the knuckles, we all know what has happened. We had a debate on uranium in the House the other day. That magnificent trio, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and the Labor senator for the Northern Territory, told their colleagues, `It is all nonsense. With this three-mine policy of yours, you do not know what you are about'. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is saying the same thing. Where is this doctrine of ministerial responsibility? What is the Labor Party's policy?

What is really happening is that, because there is about to be a conference, the Prime Minister is a bit embarrassed because he knows that his blue collar credentials are suspect and he knows that nobody in the ranks of the Labor Party believes that he is in touch with what they want. We know that Mr Hawke is a Prime Minister out of touch and progressively he is beginning to believe that, too. Three back bench members of the Labor Party and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy are saying, `For goodness sake all you other fellows in Labor Caucus, it is about time that you recognised what Australia needs. TALK.START.PARA: —It was about Qantas.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister does not have the leadership ability and he is unable to give to those who have a different point of view to his own the leadership inspiration that makes them say, `Gee, Bob, that is what I want to do for Australia'. TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to the comments of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) later. SPEECH.PARA: It is on the record that it was the honourable member for Bennelong who nearly deregulated the financial market, who nearly floated the dollar, who nearly reduced expenditure in the areas of government expenditure and appropriation, who nearly removed the unfair tariffs and protections that ought not have been there, who nearly reconstructed the tax system, who nearly introduced the broad based consumption tax and who nearly cracked down on tax evasion and all the rorts that went on across this nation, particularly from 1976 to 1983. They have been badly orchestrated and pathetically argued, they have usually been hypocritical, and most have been so well off the mark that people do not bother to listen to them any more.

Those opposite have launched attacks on poverty, yet they do not bother to realise the strategy that is now in place and working across this nation, helping the many hundreds of thousands of low income families. We have also heard the Opposition's vicious attacks on unions. I suggest that, except for the doctors' disputes, there has been general industrial peace in the workplace right across the land. Calls have been made for tax restructuring, but it is the Labor Government that has taken the action.

The matters of public importance that have been brought forward have been nothing but crocodile tears. They have been brought forward in a desperate attempt by the Opposition day after day to latch on to some issue-any issue. It does not matter what it is, provided they can grab something to growl about. Today's matter of public importance is typical. It is like so many that have come before-criticism without foundation, a tongue in cheek approach. The wording of the matter of public importance oozes with hypocrisy. It is quite laughable for the Opposition ever to talk about ministerial responsibility. It is quite laughable for it ever to talk about cohesion and direction of policy.

Here we have, in 1988, a Liberal and National Opposition that is the most divided opposition, the most divided coalition, since Federation. It has no political cohesion, no political direction, no clear ideological position and no decisive leadership. It is a conglomeration of small groups of conservative politicians whose only common characteristic is that they are devoid of ideas and initiative but are anti-Labor. It is the only thing that seems to bring them together. They are totally undependable when it comes to what they believe in. No-one in the business world or in the community seems to know what they believe. They do not have a policy position, a policy stance.

I thought that was what it was all about. Another difference is that the Government has the characteristics of certainty and consistency, and we cannot find that in the Opposition.

The Leader of the Opposition talked about backbenchers saying what they want to. Is that a crime? Is it wrong for backbenchers to have a differing point of view when no specific policy decision has been made by the Government? I suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that he look at what the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) had to say in the debate on the consumption tax and in the referendum debate. We need look only at the tax policies of the Queensland National Party, the Federal National Party, the Liberal machine, the Liberal wets and the Liberal dries. It is as if the Leader of the Opposition is an apprentice bullocky trying to goad and coax his load of logs down the political road. He has the lead yoke around his neck but his team is pulling away in every direction, down different tracks. That seems to be the situation. As the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) said, he is trying to put up a smokescreen. He realises the problem he has in his own Party and he is trying to make some sort of cover-up. Well, it is not working. We know what is going on. We know that the conflict exists.

I wonder how many people appreciate just how far away the Leader of the Opposition really is from the consensus, the attitudes and the policies that have been adopted by the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party's 1987 policy document states:
The hallmark of our system of justice is the right to trial by jury.
That is the hallmark of the Liberal Party policy. It continues:

And what are those opposite doing? Now that we in the Government are changing the Constitution to allow trial by jury, the Liberal Party and the National Party are opposed to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hypocrites.
