DEBATE.TITLE: ANTI-DUMPING AUTHORITY BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:CUSTOMS LEGISLATION(ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS)BILL 1988CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 April, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill concurrently with the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping Amendment) Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill are a consequence of the Government's response to the review of the Customs Tariffs Anti-Dumping Act carried out by Professor Gruen. This review was completed in March 1986, so there really has not been what one might call a shattering rush to implement the recommendations of the Gruen report. When one looks at the activity currently taking place in the customs area one wonders whether it would not be more appropriate, seeing that the Law Reform Commission is looking at the whole of the Customs Act, to refer this matter to that inquiry. It has taken such a long time, over two years, to get to this stage and a major review is still being carried on. In essence another layer of administration is being put into the customs pot while a review of the whole of the Customs Act is being undertaken by the Law Reform Commission. It is quite strange, especially when we have waited over two years for this legislation in response to the Gruen report. I guess that is a result of poor management.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, the Bills are a response to the Gruen report. They amend the anti-dumping legislation to implement some of the recommendations of the Gruen inquiry. The Anti-Dumping Authority Bill creates a new statutory authority to administer the anti-dumping mechanisms set up in the two Bills which accompany it. So we have two amending Bills and one establishing an authority. It will be a one member Anti-Dumping Authority headed by someone outside the Public Service. The new statutory body will advise the Minister whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed on products imported from overseas. Dumping occurs when products from one country are exported to another at less than their normal value. It is a practice which is internationally condemned as unfair trading, particularly if the dumped goods are harmful to local production in the importing country. There is a need to control dumping, but any legislation must, by its nature, be transparent-as the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) would know. It is imperative that anti-dumping measures not be used as de facto protection measures, because if there is to be protection it should be visible.

In the past Australia has made greater use of anti-dumping action than other countries. This could be potentially frustrating to the achievement of other Government objectives in industry, trade, competition and economic policy areas. In practice, anti-dumping actions hinder beneficial international commercial competition and become significant protection devices. So I hope this Bill does not foreshadow anti-dumping actions becoming even more prevalent in Australia. As I said before, if we need to protect any industry we must do it openly by imposing duties and not by back door anti-dumping devices. Also, history has shown that generally the injured party will turn out to be the exporting country which continues to dump.

It is therefore in the best interests of Australia to take the external trading environment as it exists where and when we can. There comes a time when Australian industry must become competitive enough to survive in the context of the world economic environment. There is a real need for change towards a less assisted, more outward looking, restructured industry. This does not completely preclude the need for anti-dumping measures in Australia. The Opposition agrees that there is a place for anti-dumping measures based on the principle that trade should be conducted fairly. However, anti-dumping systems must be speedily and readily available. Our present anti-dumping system certainly is lacking in some respects. It is for this reason that the Government commissioned Professor Gruen to review the anti-dumping system that applies in this nation. The review certainly received the benefit of advice from many parts of industry, and its recommendations have been taken up in this legislation.

I might add that I was responsible for customs for some time, and I found the whole area of dumping to be very complex and the causes for it sometimes very difficult to understand. In some cases there is no doubt that the action taken by the Australian producer was more in line with a protectionist approach than a dumping one. As a consequence of that, one first had to establish whether the dumping by the foreign country was real or whether the local producer had not taken the necessary steps in order to keep himself in the contemporary marketplace and was attempting to use anti-dumping laws as a way of extending his protection.

The next difficulty was that in genuine cases of dumping one could not claim injury until it occurred. The potential for dumping to occur was no reason to seek a review of a particular product. Having ascertained that injury had been occurring in Australia, the job of the Australian Customs Service to make the right decision in relation to pricing a product external to Australia was very hard, very time consuming and very costly. On many occasions we moved officers around the world to investigate various products, sometimes successfuliy and sometimes not. When trading with Japan, in particular, it is very hard to isolate a normal price. In spite of the actions of the Customs officers at that stage, ultimately only a very good guess was the basis on which decisions were made. So I can understand the predicament the Government found itself in when addressing the Gruen report. The main provisions which come from that report are welcomed by the Opposition as they offer a way through the maze.

However, we disagree with some aspects of the detail in the Bills. The main provisions of the legislation are as follows: it establishes a one-man Anti-Dumping Authority; policy guidelines will be developed by the Authority and established by regulation; the life of dumping notices and undertakings will be restricted to a maximum of three years-Gruen recommended two; and it prescribes the manner in which the Australian Customs Service will conduct preliminary investigations into dumping complaints.

In addition I find that the Industries Assistance Commission Act-we debated the IAC Bill on Wednesday-will be amended once more so that the IAC is no longer responsible for dumping matters. That job will now go to the new Authority. If I were a member of the IAC these days, I would certainly be looking around for a transfer. The future does not look too good in the IAC. On Wednesday we were stripping a few things away from the IAC. We talked about the amount of money spent on the IAC, the Government's main advisory body on industry. Its money is going down. Certainly even the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) could not say that the IAC legislation does not strip it of dumping. Certainly my recommendation to members of the IAC would be to look for a job transfer.

Anti-dumping complaints can now be initiated by any person on behalf of the relevant Australian industry. After preliminary investigation by the Customs Service a determination will be made about whether there is a prima facie case to warrant investigation by the new Authority. The legislation prescribes that investigations must be commenced within 70 days, and a further 180 days are allowed in which to make a preliminary finding as to whether dumping or countervailing duty should be imposed. The decisions which inevitably flow from the Customs Service are subject to review by the Authority and must be reported to the Minister within a further 120 days. Quite a period has elapsed when 70 days, then 180 days and a further 120 days pass in terms of these procedures. The Minister has total discretion and will take into account the national interest in making his final decision.

The Opposition rejects the provision which allows far too long a period for decisions to be made by the Customs Service. It seems to us that certainty and speed are essential for the injured party. I am aware that the Customs Service cannot achieve these elements without more resources. Customs has been consistently short-changed on resources over the years, particularly the allocation relating to dumping. It is a specialist area and it requires both manpower in Australia and the placing of Customs officers in areas external to this country.

If the intention of this Bill is to fix that problem, the maximum period allowable before action is taken should be shortened. We will be moving amendments, which have been circulated, to that effect at the Committee stage. The amendments relate to the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill and the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill. The Gruen review recommended 55 days and 120 days for the Customs Service to report-considerably shorter than the time recommended in the legislation. I assume that the reason for that is the Government decided that Customs would have no more resources, that it would have to make do with the current situation, so we cannot have the recommended shorter period. I understand that Canada has a 30-day and a 60-day rule. If that is the case, its resources must be infinitely greater to be able to achieve that result. I hope that the Department will press its claims for more resources because the greater the availability of resources the better will be the services that can be provided to people who are in daily contact with the Service.

Professor Gruen's main recommendation was that the provision for anti-dumping should be streamlined, simplified and clarified so that a predictable mechanism is created. That is a worthy objective and something which, in the dumping area, should be worked out. Industry requires certainty. Industry has a right to know where it stands in relation to dumping issues. I am not sure that this Bill meets that criterion. It adds another layer of bureaucracy which may or may not have the proper funding to carry out the duties with which it is vested. Gruen wanted to discourage the use of the anti-dumping system for the reasons that I mentioned earlier. This new layer of bureaucracy will promote greater use of the system as all and sundry are being encouraged to take part.
Gruen said in his report:

The anti-dumping system should not be used to shield import-competing industry from the necessity to adjust to changing longer term economic conditions-unless the IAC has at least examined the circumstances justifying such longer-term insulation from world market trends.

The Government has fixed up the IAC by removing dumping. It has certainly given Gruen the thumbs down in that regard. The concept of a new statutory body clearly indicates that this Government wonders whether it is the most effective means of curbing dumping. The team of 16 experts will be headed by a person chosen for his or her economic and commercial experience. I seriously wonder whether the Government will pay enough to attract the right sort of person to such a position. The same old problem-underfunding -is evident.

Nowhere in this legislation, either in the explanatory memorandum or in the second reading speech, do we read anything about the new Authority receiving proper resources. Even Professor Gruen admitted that the biggest problem with the dumping situation is that not enough resources are there to make anti-dumping measures effective. A body can be set up and a few public servants appointed to it, but, without the proper resources, it cannot be made to work. Gruen recommended 55 and 120 days only should be allowed. The Opposition supports that recommendation. Our proposed amendments to that effect have been distributed. In order for a speedy resolution of these disputes, it is necessary for the time limits to be lowered from those which are recommended. It is interesting to note that in Canada, as I have said, time limits are set at only 30 days and 60 days.

The Opposition does not oppose the principles of the legislation. We hope that this legislation will contribute to resolving some of the many vexing problems of dumping. This area requires professional attention. Specialists are required to be on hand to the Customs Service so it can apply itself to the very difficult task of establishing normal pricing and injury to industry. The Government's response has been slow. It has taken two years. We wonder-indeed, we doubt-whether it will be the sort of response industry requires. We wonder whether the approach is suitable and whether the timetable that is set down is quick enough. We also wonder whether the resources that ought to be placed with Customs to carry this through will be provided. Without the resources and without the timetables, there is not much hope that this contribution towards the dumping issue will resolve anything. It could create another administrative layer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for leave of the House to present revised explanatory memoranda to the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise on behalf of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who was not able to be present to hear the contribution made by the shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). The Minister assures me that he will be in the chamber for the conclusion of the debate. I present the revised explanatory memoranda to the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill. These explanatory memoranda supersede those tabled on 28 April 1988.
—How do these explanatory memoranda differ from the original ones?
—There are only minor changes.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence I ask the Minister to inform the House what circumstances have led to the tabling of the revised memoranda. Perhaps the Minister might be able to indicate whether it is as a result of rushing legislation through the House and failure to prepare the material properly.
—I understand that there are editorial and typing changes. The revised explanatory memoranda attribute some of the Government's decisions to the Gruen recommendations.
—It is not because of rushing, is it, or because there was not enough time for proper preparation of the material?

—No, it is not because of rushing. I have just explained what it is all about. I am sure that the Minister will be here at the end of the debate to explain this matter fully. The honourable member may then like to ask the Minister questions.
—It sounds like a bungled job.
—No, it is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dumping is one of the most sensitive, emotive and probably misunderstood areas of the operations of the Australian Customs Service. It is also true to say that it is one of the most ruthless, exploitive and dangerous practices in international trade and should, wherever practicable, be legislated against or penalised in such ways as are open to governments. Proof of dumping is very difficult. It is difficult also to convince the majority of those who are affected by imports that dumping is not taking place. Certainly, it is necessary that a country such as Australia, where large industrial bases do not exist in all areas, is protected from short-term and long term dumping which can have the effect of wiping out local industries with no prospects of a local source replacing them, to be followed by exploitation of the Australian market. The Anti-Dumping Authority Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill change the arrangements in a number of ways. They also place the final responsibility for decision making in this process squarely with the government of the day, through the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the arrangements which are covered by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), there are limited options for a government to protect its own industries against a sudden influx of dumped products over a short period. I am not sure that this piece of legislation deals fully with that problem. It is of concern that where an importer or a foreign seller chooses to enter the Australian market with goods at non-competitive prices, on either a short or a long term arrangement, the response times and the provisions which exist to penalise the person undertaking the dumping are such as to make such a venture a very low risk commercial operation.

Under the present arrangements, only the person or firm directly affected by dumping is permitted to initiate, by right, an anti-dumping action. There have been a number of cases where foreign firms with subsidiaries in Australia but controlled outside Australia were involved in dumping to the detriment of employees of and suppliers to Australian firms in a way which was quite unfair and unscrupulous. This legislation changes the right to initiate an anti-dumping action in that it extends that `by right' provision to employees or their representatives and also to other firms, such as suppliers who are or could be affected.

The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) indicated in his second reading speech that, where a prima facie case of dumping is established, he will usually exercise his power for retrospective application of an anti-dumping duty to the date which is provided for by law. That is a deterrent in itself in that it effectively takes away a positive advantage which exists in the present circumstances whereby a person or a firm who imports or dumps goods in Australia can fairly safely expect to benefit for an extended period whilst hearings are held and decisions are made in respect of the dumped imports. It does not altogether resolve the problem of that advantage. I have raised the position-I have been informed that it is not possible under the GATT arrangements-whereby alternate sourcing take place, thus circumventing the anti-dumping legislation.

It is possible to spot purchase a substantial range of goods, dump them in Australia and not be subject to this legislation in any way because the time frames which are involved and the time at which an anti-dumping duty can first be applied will not cover goods already in Australia when the complaint is lodged and goods from the source where it is not intended by the importer to re-supply. It is possible to change sources-and there are ample sources available of many goods which can be dumped against Australian industry-and to continue to dump goods in Australia with little or no penalty. I believe that that is a weakness in the legislation or the GATT arrangements. Certainly, it is a serious weakness in a world in which it is not unusual for countries to subsidise exports, such as is happening against our primary products in other parts of the world. The legislation restricts the times for each of the stages of hearing of an anti-dumping application. They are still fairly long and present a situation where at least some damage can occur to an Australian industry which may not be in a position to compete with lower priced, high-volume goods over any extended period.

The one other concern I have about the legislation is that, where dumping is re-sourced, there are no penalties and there is no automatic establishment of a prima facie case that the re-sourced goods have been dumped and that, on such a finding being established, anti-dumping duties will be made retrospective to those re-sourced goods, a person having already been found to have dumped goods from the original source. It is not an adequate protection that a person who has been found guilty of acting contrary to the Australian law can, merely by re-sourcing his goods, commit the same indiscretion again and be exempt from any form of penalty. The worst penalty that can apply to that person is that he is asked to pay the proper price for the imports which arrive in this country. There is a very distinct commercial encouragement in this legislation and the dumping arrangements for persons to involve themselves in sourcing from other areas because there are no effective penalties.

I wish to deal with one other matter, which is broader than the dumping issue itself. Unfortunately, there is in the community some confusion as to the difference between anti-dumping legislation and protection as such. It is not a bad thing that the proposed Anti-Dumping Authority will be divorced from the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). I noticed some cross-chamber discussion before. I would think that the IAC has about the same record of acceptance of its reports as the Remuneration Tribunal has about its reports. It does not have a very high scoring record. But the IAC, through the process of tariffs, quotas and other forms of restriction of entry on a permanent basis, is responsible for providing protection to Australian industry, on a short or long-term basis, from normal competition. The anti-dumping legislation is not supposed to be a form of long-term protection. Therefore, it is appropriate that there is a sunset clause on the length of time in which a matter can be subject to anti-dumping procedures. If dumping were to be still continuing after a period of three years, or the potential was there for that to occur, the matter should have been dealt with in that time by an appropriate reference to the IAC, through the methods which are established to provide protection to industry on a permanent basis.

To put it bluntly, I think that Australia's attitude on protection is holier than thou. We are leaving ourselves in a position where we can argue with some moral certainty for greater trading freedom around the world. Unfortunately, other countries, the United States in particular, which talk about freeing of trade do not practise it. The United States is involved in as heavy dumping arrangements as any country anywhere in the world. We need access to overseas markets. For obvious reasons we cannot afford to act in a way which will cause problems in our existing export markets. Equally, we cannot afford to allow our industries to go down the drain through unfair trading practices when such industries are competitive and when, after our industries have been removed, the prices for goods immediately move up. There are plenty of examples of that.

I support the legislation. However, I have reservations about the extent to which it provides an adequate mechanism to protect against blatant and, what I consider bordering on criminal, dumping which occurs on occasions. I am informed that because of our international agreements the legislation cannot carry the types of arrangements which I would prefer to see in place. I am not advocating that we should have restrictions on imports for the sake of restrictions. However, where persons, firms, countries or otherwise are involved in blatantly unfair trade practices, I believe our industries are as entitled to protection as theirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke-Keating Government has attempted to project an image as a deregulatory, free trade oriented administrator of industry and trade policy. However, apart from active work against agricultural subsidies, quotas and protection, the Government's record is one of mediocrity. Australian industry remains highly protected as European and American trade negotiators consistently point out. The Government has actively interfered in industry through a series of interventionist plans which protect trade union influence, as much as industry itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The Anti-Dumping Authority Bill and cognate Bills continue the Government's record of rhetoric which is not matched by action. It is not surprising therefore that the second reading speech of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) was riddled with contradictions. The only substantially accurate assertion is that this legislation is in accordance with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). However, that is also true of a lot of the agricultural protection which Australia has correctly queried and challenged. The GATT negotiations represent the lowest common denominator result of the divergent ideas and interests of many countries which are not exactly themselves models of open trading economies. The standard set in GATT negotiations must be considered the minimal condition for free trade. It should not be the standard by which the Australian Government is judged. The standard should be the interests of Australians as consumers, farmers, miners or those involved in other businesses. By that measure, this legislation fails. It fails because no matter what rhetoric is used to justify retaliatory anti-dumping legislation, its effect is to protect local industry. Professor Fred Gruen wrote in the Australian Financial Review of 4 May 1988:

Anti-dumping policies are used predominantly by certain rich, unadaptable economies . . . which find it politically easier to use anti-dumping techniques for protecting their industries than to allow their industries to compete freely.

Under this legislation, Professor Gruen's assessment will be particularly relevant to our country. It is now proposed to set up yet another government authority, the Anti-Dumping Authority, which will have its own interests in ensuring that anti-dumping measures play an important role in Australian trade policy. The Minister argues:
Dumping occurs when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value in the country of export.

Put simply, if the Australian consumer can get a better price than overseas consumers because of local market conditions, heavy competition, subsidy or the aggressive marketing of overseas companies, that cheaper product could become the subject of a dumping complaint. The criterion upholding that complaint is to be whether pricing causes or threatens material injury to the industry producing like goods in the importing country.

If a complaint is upheld, dumping duties can be imposed raising the price of the good for the consumer and removing the need for Australian producers to match the lower price. I ask the House: How does this differ from the most common arguments for protection? Certainly, it has the same effect as traditional protection on the price of overseas goods if they are considered dumped. The difference is that anti-dumping legislation is cloaked in terms such as `fair trade' and `a retaliatory response to unfair trade practices'. In reality it represents a return to concepts of international trade-no more, no less than that. Cynics, as well as respected economists, have suggested that the worldwide increase in anti-dumping legislation in recent years has more to do with the fact that it is the only form of protection considered legitimate in the GATT rules than it has to do with a sudden increase in the practice of dumping.

Anti-dumping legislation represents a specific case of a belief in retaliatory protection. In the context of world trade that is the metaphorical equivalent to the prisoner's dilemma. It is the very reason for the existence of GATT. There is little evidence that anti-dumping legislation is a successful strategy, while there is a good deal of evidence to suggest that the differential pricing which can attract dumping complaints is actually in the interests of the importing nation.

As the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) should, and I am sure would, be aware, the idea of fair trade which is referred to by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business in his second reading speech, is the rational for most protectionist trade proposals in the United States. The idea of fair trade fails to distinguish between the commercial decisions of private business and the efforts of government to protect or subsidise local industry. I suggest that that is a distinction which this legislation also fails to draw. Economist George Yarrow has argued:

Many supporters of anti-dumping measures base their case on the argument that the legislation serves to promote fair trade, without explaining why a business practice as widespread as price discrimination should be regarded as unfair.

In the absence of any detailed elaboration of the criterion of fairness that is being employed, such arguments strike me simply as being empty. Empty is probably the only apt description of this legislation. In a recent Press release the Minister warned importers against unfair-for `unfair' one can read `competitive'-trade practices and assured industry that this legislation would be used vigorously. Surely the use of legislation must be determined by the actual trading practices as they emerge. By promising vigorous anti-dumping activity the Minister is pre-empting the market and assuring local industry that this legislation will be actively used to protect it from foreign competition in more circumstances than it might reasonably have expected.

The assessment that the anti-dumping legislation will act as a protectionist measure is reinforced by the divergence between the legislation before us today and Professor Fred Gruen's review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act which preceded it. Professor Gruen's report emphasised the need to treat predatory pricing by foreign imports in the same way as similar practices by local companies, as well as the need for efficiency and certainty in processing anti-dumping complaints. Indeed, the Minister himself has said:
The extent of dumping essentially depends on the health of the world economy and the relative competitiveness of the Australian economy.

He indicates that the price discrimination that is often known as dumping results from surpluses of products that will be temporary and conditions in the Australian economy which are beyond the control of importers. As to predatory pricing where foreigners dump their goods to destroy the local industry, then switch to exploiting us by monopolistic high prices, Leyland Yeager has written that `this case is seldom if ever documented, for such tricks would scarcely work'.

Strict limits must be placed on the imposition of dumping penalties. I am not heartened in that prospect by the Press statement from the Minister to which I referred earlier. In the United States 94 per cent of complaints about unfair trade practices are upheld. That is a salutary lesson that would not be lost on industry generally. Too often Australian firms consider lodging dumping complaints only when they notice that the competition is getting rather stiff. The entire complaints procedure, although widespread, asks for companies and now other interests to make a dumping complaint which, if upheld, will have the effect of protecting them from competition. The goal of the firm complaining is, rightly, to maximise profit and its market share. It is not interested in the concept of `fair' trade. Any cheaper product is a potential threat, no matter what the reason for the lower price. Anti-dumping duties simply offer a cost effective way of defeating competition. That is the way local entrepreneurs have used it and will continue to use it. The outcome is that the Australian consumer loses the benefit of the cheaper goods.

In summary, I caution the Government against the extensive use of anti-dumping legislation. It has been used in the past as a form of protection and can easily be used for that purpose in the future. The Government has avoided the tough decision to overhaul completely the relevant legislation, as recommended by Professor Gruen. Instead, it has set up yet another bureaucratic Government authority.

We can still learn from the wisdom of Adam Smith. I am pleased to see my friend the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) here today because he referred us to Adam Smith the other night in another context. In 1776 Adam Smith wrote:
In every country it always is and must be the interest of the great body of the people to buy whatever they want of those who sell it cheapest.

The proposition is so very manifest, that it seems ridiculous to take any pains to prove it; nor could it ever have been called in question, had not the interested sophistry of merchants and manufacturers confounded the common sense of mankind.
Wonderful words indeed, and they have an application here. Under this legislation we must now add the trade union movement to the list of those who practise `interested sophistry'.
Amendment (by Mr Moore)-by leave-proposed:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) further complicating customs procedures; and

(2) adding another layer of bureaucracy thus increasing costs to the customs service while still denying the service the expertise recommended for it in the Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), particularly his quote from Adam Smith. His words are undoubtedly a truism: any consumer would obviously want to buy the cheapest goods available in the marketplace. When one talks about dumping, tariffs and international trade, of course that situation does not apply. I shall refer as an example for the honourable member to a recent case involving tyre dumping in this country and I will prove to anyone's satisfaction that the person who profits least from dumping is in fact the consumer. The reality is that dumping occurs in a country such as Australia only because an importer sees a great opportunity to make not just profit but rather super profit, and inevitably the super profit is paid by the consumer. One must question whether that sort of activity is in the interests of international trade and in the interests of any nation that allows it to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: In a recent case of tyre dumping, it was clearly established that tyres were being dumped in this country at up to 58 per cent; in other words, they were being imported into this country 58 per cent cheaper than their nominal value in the country in which they were produced. For those unfamiliar with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and GATT terms, nominal value is a GATT expression; and the GATT rules with which this country complies basically provide that an importer cannot import into a country goods with a nominal value less than that in the country of origin which will cause material injury to a local industry. Basically, that is what GATT says, but GATT does not define what is nominal value or causal connection or material injury to a local industry. In the case of these tyres, a lot were imported by Mr Jane of Bob Jane T-Mart, a national tyre retailing firm. Having established clearly that the tyres were dumped at up to 58 per cent under nominal value, if one looks at the price at which the importer, Mr Jane, sells those tyres, one will inevitably find that they are marketed at only $1, $2 or $3 under the price of the Australian produced competitive goods.

I defy anyone to say that there is any benefit to a consumer in such an arrangement. Indeed, the tyres imported are high quality tyres; they are well known brand name tyres; they are a popular European brand of tyres. But the consumer has not received the benefit. The only benefit, of course, has gone to the importer, who has not made a profit; he has made a super profit. I was fascinated to read a letter dated 11 May 1988 from Mr Jane addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), a copy of which was circulated to all Caucus members. Mr Jane points out that he is a big independent tyre dealer and says that it does not worry him whether he imports tyres or not; he will still make a profit in this country. He suggests in his letter that we have high priced tyres in this country and that if he imports tyres-no doubt at a cheaper price-the consumer will be better off. I publicly suggest to Mr Jane that, when I see him selling dumped tyres at a much lower market price than is available from Australian manufacturers, I will agree with his concern that Australians should be able to get cheaper tyres and that there is any consumer benefit to them at all.

I might add that that particular tyre dumping case concerned me greatly when I read about it; because I do not understand how any person can possibly find that tyres dumped at up to 58 per cent against Australian produced goods do not cause material injury to an Australian manufacturer. Such a suggestion defies logic and reason. If someone imports 100,000 tyres of a popular size in a well known brand and sells them in this country, a manufacturer in this country will produce 100,000 tyres less in that given year. That is so logical to my way of thinking that, when I read this anti-dumping report and the report found that there was no material injury, I did do my banana a little bit, one could say, and made some rather strong comments to the Minister concerned; and particularly having met some of the members of the Customs Service, I told them what I thought of their bureaucratic jargon and their lack of concern for the maintenance of Australian industry.

Whatever one may say in a rational economic sense about tariffs or dumping, ultimately the bottom line is surely jobs. If importers can import at dumped prices to compete against an Australian manufacturer and this country is not going to do anything about it, the reality is that industries which are facing what the honourable member referred to as competition will go out of business. Those industries will not be here to produce those goods; and why should they? How can any Australian manufacturer, in the case of such products as tyres, compete against a country that will dump them at 58 per cent? The bottom line in closing down industry is, of course, jobs. If industry is being competed against on such terms and we do not protect those industries to ensure fair and proper competition, the bottom line is that men and women will lose their jobs in this country.

I have given notice, and I will say it again in this House, that I will fight incessantly and vehemently to ensure that the people I represent do not lose their jobs because of unfair trade practices and dumping. I will not accept it, and if the Opposition has a different view, let it come out and talk about the family, as Opposition members like to do, because the ultimate security for any family in this country is a job. I will also go out and fight and argue against protection. I will argue for industry change and for reduced protection, but I will never accept unfair competition and dumping.

Who is doing the dumping in international trade? The dumping of cement is a good example. It is being alleged at the moment by the cement manufacturers that Japan is dumping cement in this country at up to 68 per cent under its nominal value. If that is the case, why should Australia allow a country such as Japan, one of its major trading partners, to dump cement here when it will not allow Australia to sell its beef in Japan? What is the logic of an exporting nation such as Australia allowing a country that positively discriminates against all the rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and refuses to comply with them to dump cement here in a way that will cause loss of Australian industry, Australian profit and, at the bottom line, Australian jobs?

I refer next to cotton, felt and textiles, and note that coveralls from China are dumped in Australian at about 48 per cent. There is a coverall factory in my electorate at Seymour, Jones Workwear, which employs many women in that country town. If the factory closed its doors about 100 men and women would be out of work, and there are no other job opportunities in Seymour. The Victorian Government is about to retrench some railway employees as well, and unemployment is quite high in this rural town. I have not heard anyone yet explain the logic of allowing any country to bring in coveralls at 48 per cent under the nominal value, which is dumping, when the effect of that will be that Australian men and women, workers and families, will lose their jobs.

As I pointed out in regard to the tyre situation, the retailers will not sell the goods much more cheaply. That is super profit; it is of no benefit to consumers. Retailers do not give a damn whether in the end Australians lose their jobs because of dumping as long as they maintain high profit ratios. Although we should always support free enterprise and the removal of tariffs, and throughout the world we should loudly proclaim that we want to have free trade and to be part of a world where fair and open competition is a possibility, and support it, why should Australia bare its soul and breast to those countries which damage so much of its trade, and be kicked in the teeth for it? The bottom line is jobs, and I will not wear it.

This Bill will go a long way to tightening the current controls, and I hope the people involved in administering the new Anti-Dumping Authority which will be established will remember what their role is. Their role is not to protect outside countries; it is not to play games with GATT; it is not to interpret legislation to ensure that the importer gets a fair cop out of the bureaucrats. Their job is to ensure that Australian industries and Australians get a fair shake from the people they employ and that protection is given where necessary and where unfair trade advantage is being taken, so that the people whom we on this side of the House represent-the ordinary men and women of this country-will be guaranteed that their jobs are safe. That is what this new Anti-Dumping Authority should be told to do. I am pleased that the Minister made some very strong comments on this matter in his second reading speech. I said before, and I will say it again until people get sick of hearing it, that I will not under any circumstances accept dumping in this country where it will affect industries and jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps there is no matter that comes before this House that taxes the public and business and industry as much as this very sensitive area of tariffs. I am speaking on behalf of the National Party of Australia, which has been accused in the dim, distant past of being the party that created the impetus to impose tariff barriers through a system of duties to protect Australian industry. When Sir John McEwen was doing that, he acted with the motive not only of enabling Australia to trade better on international markets, but also of protecting home markets, because he realised that the balance of trade position-our current account position-depended as much on import substitution manufacturing as it did on selling to the outside world. The unfortunate result now before us is that tariffs have allowed industries to be protected behind that wall, and the efficiency that they were expected to create did not eventuate.

SPEECH.PARA: A few myths have been perpetuated through the country in the minds of many people in financial and industrial fields that tariffs are a widespread influence in Australia at the moment and are used to protect Australia's inefficient industries against outside competition. Primary industry receives very little protection, and is able to fight a determined battle only because of the efficiency of industry leaders and the industry itself. The manufacturing industry is not highly protected either. There are some taxation incentives available in all the areas of industry that may be regarded as some type of protection. I do not regard them as protection; I say they are incentives. We have seen new growth in the technical area but again there is not a great deal of protection there.

Australian industry is subsidised to some extent, but it stands in the field of international competition suffering from abnormal costs compared with its international competitors in Europe, Japan and the United States of America. In those places the European Economic Community (EEC) has long been acknowledged as being a corrupt type of market structure against which to try to sell goods because of the high incidence of subsidy. For instance, in the sugar industry, in which I have been involved for many years, the amount of subsidy provided to EEC sugar was greater than the price that the Australian grower could obtain at any time, which was about $230 to $300 a tonne. Compared with the other countries I mentioned, Australia also pays abnormal costs of production. Because of our geography, transport costs in Australia for minerals and primary products are so abnormal that one hesitates to compare them with the transport costs of any other country in the world. Australia also has a sparse population. The cost of fuel in Australia should also be considered. Australia is not self-dependent for its oil and must import it. Australia's interest rates are still way out of proportion compared with those of its international competitors. Our taxing regime is also out of proportion. By comparison with people in the countries I mentioned earlier, Australians in industry pay a much higher rate of tax. I mention as an example the imposition of the fringe benefits tax, which is a definite detriment to trade in Australia.

The last matter I mention is industrial relations. In a limited time last night honourable members tried to debate this matter and bring out its full effects. There is no doubt that the Australian industrial situation is unique, and that that uniqueness imposes a penalty on industry. Australian industry is already behind the eight ball when it comes to competition with the outside world because of these in-built factors. I would just like to dispel the myth that Australians are heavily subsidised and protected by tariffs. That is not the case at all.

This anti-dumping legislation is really an extension of protection against corrupt international competition, particularly where an industry is trying to import substitutes so as to maintain a presence in the Australian domestic market. An industry may be faced with competition from outside by way of goods being dumped at below their cost of production. As a result, the Australian industry is affected. I believe that, as we go into the 1990s, no industry in Australia can expect a government of any persuasion to heavily subsidise it or protect it against outside influences. The only protection that an industry has is the efficiency with which it applies itself to manufacturing or providing services.

Another interesting aspect in the Gruen Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act is the point that devaluation has had the effect of giving a protection to Australian industry. The difficulty that we face there is that the duties that were being applied were not reduced in line with the devaluation of the dollar. In fact, we built up a wall of protection because the rates of duty were not adjusted in line with the devaluation of the dollar. That is now being corrected, but I am afraid that it was left in place too long. As a consequence, many industries in Australia that were afforded extra protection did not get out and rationalise and expand in the manner in which they might have been able to.

I would like to deal with a few of the problems that have arisen in the past. The fact is that it is time that some action was taken in this regard. There are problems throughout the world with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In a way, those problems are not unrelated to anti-dumping because they also relate to protection and subsidies. There has been a problem in the past, particularly with seasonal horticultural crops, in terms of the time within which an application could be made and the resulting penalty this could impose on an importer. For instance, supermarkets have been able to bring in cheaper horticultural goods at dumped prices. This applied to Californian oranges and Israeli grapefruit as well as canned food from Europe. In all cases there was a difficulty in trying to reach a position either in respect of the primary producer in connection with the raw product or in respect of the canners in connection with competition from the outside manufacturer. I am afraid I have to say-and I have been told-that often supermarkets would not hesitate to penalise the Australian product by way of inferred blackmail. I believe that that is offensive, especially in light of the fact that the major supermarkets-I believe that there are four or five chains which command 80 per cent of the market-are able to act in such a way. So the Gruen report is timely and should be considered.

The Gruen review was commissioned in 1986 and it has taken a little while to come to fruition in legislation form. This legislation is an attempt to get around some of the problems that I have mentioned. One of Professor Gruen's recommendations was designed to ensure that, wherever possible, the market price in the country of origin would be used for the purposes of comparison with the local price subject to a dumping complaint. Such a procedure is the only fair method of assessment for all parties to the complaint. It avoids the turmoil of the `United States costs', plus a margin for anti-dumping procedures, which has been the subject of scandal and manipulation by industry and the bureaucracy in that country. The Government has rejected that very sensible recommendation of its own report. The reason for that rejection was that countries such as the European Economic Community and the United States use provisions like section 55 (9). However, it is the experience of those very countries which lead to the conclusion that Professor Gruen was right.

The attempt to tighten criteria in section 55 (9) is an improvement on the existing law, but it fails to provide the certainty which importers are entitled to. Under the legislation now before us, the time allowed for investigation of anti-dumping complaints is considerably longer than that recommended in the Gruen report. Complaints need not be finally determined for over six months. This presents an unnecessary restraint on the trading operations of private companies. The Government has provided no rationale for this change from the Gruen report. We can only assume that the Minister for Customs, Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) does not believe that the Australian Customs Service and his new Anti-Dumping Authority will be able to meet the standards of efficiency hoped for in those proposals.

This legislation, like most anti-dumping legislation, has inherent flaws. One of the most difficult problems encountered overseas is in defining goods and the markets in which they are competing. Should a `dumped' good which causes product substitution become subject to dumping duty? At what stage can that substitution be identified? What of Australian firms that alter their production on the assumption of cheaper goods or a good deal from overseas? Is steel roofing in competition with plastic alternatives? These are very important questions that have to be thought through by the Authority.

Modern products are diverse and yet are often easily compared with similar local products. I view with some scepticism the new Authority which this legislation establishes. However, I also view the legislation as a means by which the Government has sought to come to grips with putting a specialised team into the area to deal especially with these dumping procedures. We need to ensure that there are no delays and that no penalties are incurred by frivolous or mischievous complaints by Australian industry. We also need to make sure that we flatten out international competition in the import substitution industry which is a problem and the subject of complaint. It is a pity that the Authority lacks some of the teeth and expertise that Gruen suggested it should have. I only hope that the Government will take this into account, together with Professor Gruen's comment about reducing time as far as procedures are concerned and not increasing it as this Government has done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I will make sure that my remarks are very brief because a number of my colleagues want to contribute to the debate and they have some substantial points to make. I want to talk a little about the history of this matter. On coming to office in 1983 the Government found the need for a wide-ranging review of anti-dumping matters. In 1984 a number of significant changes were put into effect. It became clear to many of us that that was not enough. Although the Government commissioned the Gruen Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act in 1986, it is fair to say that many government members took a pretty deep interest in the issue and went out to look for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I have such an example in my own electorate. The visit by the country task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Castle Bacon Pty Ltd ham and bacon plant at Castlemaine was one such instance where we were able to look directly at the effect of dumped tinned hams from the European Economic Community on the local manufacturing industry. It was through that process that I certainly became much more aware of the need for us to move to a policy which requires importers to show that their products are not being dumped rather than reacting to problems that are being created in our economy. I do not say, from my own point of view, that we have yet gone far enough. But it may be that the new measures put in place what I would call a pro-active rather than a reactive approach.

I commend the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) for his work, even in recent weeks, in final consultations with members of the back bench to ensure that these measures are meeting the needs, as we see them, at the grass roots level. I know that the Minister will be delighted at my mention of the Castlemaine example because he has visited that provincial city and has a pretty deep interest in the welfare of the manufacturing and textile processing industries in that area-the other sorts of industries that are trying to play their role as Australia becomes what I would call the Sweden of the Pacific region. We would like to think that we are now turning our emphasis to value-added manufacturing and services. As we do this, we must ensure that we protect these industries from unfair competition. I feel that these measures are a big step in the right direction and I commend the Minister for that.

I wind up with one statement that will remain in the back of my mind; that is, as we go down this path of restructuring, tariff reduction and the other steps that we are taking, we must bear in mind that Australia cannot be the only free trader in the world. Having said that, I am pleased to support the legislation. I welcome the Minister's initiative in implementing the results of the Gruen Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 and at the same time foreshadowing, as he has by his recent actions, a willingness to remain close to the pulse on these issues and to ensure that these measures not only are seen to be effective but are actually working to the benefit of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) I must at least acknowledge that in this afternoon's debate on the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill he has been a man of his word, for he said that he would be brief and brief indeed he was. I will begin at the point where the honourable member for Burke left off with his reference to a level playing field. No matter what team sports Australians are involved in, whether it is football, basketball and so on, they expect the field on which they play to be level. We go further than that. Should there be a quagmire at one end of the field or should there, because of the way the wind is blowing, be an advantage to one team, we ensure under our sporting rules that all is done to spread the advantage evenly by swapping ends on either a quarterly or half-time basis. We are obsessed with ensuring that in the sporting field everyone plays on a level surface and that an advantage that is artificially given to one team is also made available to the other team. Hence the term mentioned by the honourable member for Burke-a level playing field. Sadly, that sort of equity is not always available to Australian traders, and it is certainly not available to the Australian primary producers whom I rise to represent in the House this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: As you are aware, Madam Deputy Speaker, Australian primary producers are forced by the very nature of their operation to play on a field that is not necessarily level or equitable, or at least they are forced to produce on such a field. Some will face the reality of a season of floods and for others in a continent as vast as ours there is the reality of drought; while for others there will be fire, hail and frost. Who knows what will happen to make the existing playing field inequitable. However, they accept that that level of inequity in production is inevitable. What they seek from the Government, because no-one can reasonably expect the Government to account in any sense for the inequity that exists in production, is an opportunity to trade with equity. To pick up where the honourable member for Burke left off, they expect an opportunity to trade on a level playing field. I acknowledge that the Government had been keen, as the Opposition has been keen, to ensure that Australian primary producers and all Australian manufacturers have the opportunity to trade in an environment that is as equitable as possible.

The Government has been diligent, and I acknowledge the role played by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) in doing what they can to counter the subsidised competition that we must face as primary producers in a trade environment. Both of them are anxious to see that the unlevel playing field of the trading environment in which we are forced to operate as primary producers, currently eroded by the actions of the European Economic Community and the United States of America, is made as level as possible in the future.

I also note that the Government has been anxious to ensure that non-tariff barriers that exist around the world and the import substitution that occurs are kept to a minimum. In the legislation before the House this afternoon a real effort is being made to ensure that that other area of inequity, the area of dumping surplus production, is kept under some sort of control. I represent a group of Australian primary producers who believe they can take on all-comers in the world market, but who acknowledge that when those who take them on choose to dump produce in Australia it is difficult to have the sort of muscle that is necessary to match that form of unfair competition. The legislation before the House is designed to minimise the damage being done to Australian industry as a result of dumping techniques that might be employed by our overseas competitors. I think that we would find bipartisan agreement for the simple truth that dumping is intolerable and that the dumping of subsidised production onto the Australian market may well do damage that is irreversible to an existing Australian industry.

I take up a point or two made by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) earlier in the debate. He said that, as a result of the reality of the dumping of produce in Australia, the difficulty is that consumers do not benefit at all and the profits made by those who choose to dump produce in Australia are not passed on to the consumer. That is really not right. While I understand the sentiments that motivated that statement, the truth is that in a nation like ours the consumer chooses to purchase only what appeals to him or her, as honourable members may recall me saying yesterday. Unless the person who dumps produce in Australia is prepared to put it on the market cheaper than existing Australian produce, it will not be purchased. There is some short term benefit for the consumer in the reality of dumped produce being made available in the Australian market. I say that with some conviction because prior to becoming a member of this House I was a citrus grower; and I am very much aware of the fact that what attracted Australians to purchase either dumped oranges or, much more likely, dumped citrus juice was the fact that it was available to them at a cheaper price. There was some consumer benefit.

The other point made by the honourable member for McEwen which cannot be overlooked is his statement that the sole criterion for fighting any dumping that occurs on the Australian market should be the provision of jobs for Australians. That is a fair enough sentiment, but it is not realistic because there are some instances where merely having an anti-dumping provision in order to protect jobs is in itself counterproductive. If all that we did in this House was to pass legislation that protected jobs, we would have to ask ourselves why it is that we allow our farmers, for example, to drive tractors instead of horse teams. The provision of jobs is not the sole criterion for the anti-dumping provisions now before the House.

In the few minutes left to me I will deal with the two crops with which I am most familiar and which have been most adversely affected as a result of produce dumping in Australia and on whose behalf I will make some comments about the legislation now before the House. As I alluded to a few moments ago, I consider myself to be reasonably familiar with the citrus industry. One of the dilemmas faced by the citrus industry in Australia, and one of the dilemmas partially addressed by this legislation, is the reality of the Brazilians choosing to dump concentrated orange juice onto the Australian market.

The problem with that whole concept was not that Australian producers were inefficient. In fact, they were happy to take on any one of the other producer countries around the world in any one of the whole fruit markets around the world. But such was the state of the Brazilian economy only last year that the Brazilians were keen to turn their citrus juice lake into foreign exchange in order to meet some of their indebtedness around the world. They did not mind dumping citrus juice onto the Australian market or any other market in order to generate the foreign exchange they needed. The cost of production was meaningless. They had a lake of citrus juice that they wanted to turn into foreign exchange, and that was what motivated them. They did it in order to help to meet part of their national debt but, worse than that, they did it as a country currently enjoying Third World tariff preference. They already had an advantage over Australian producers-an advantage Australian producers did not deny them but which they subsequently chose to exploit to the disadvantage of Australian producers.

The citrus industry-I have been speaking to its general secretary, Mr Hugh Cope-is concerned that in the legislation currently before the House there is no provision for removing the onus of proof so that the industry no longer has to prove that subsidised products cause injury to an Australian industry. Madam Deputy Speaker, you will recognise just how much damage can be done to a seasonal industry such as the citrus industry when that industry's leaders are obliged to prove that damage is being done and that its major overseas competitors are dumping produce in Australia. How does one get to Brazil to discover its real cost of production? How does one establish a dumping level? That responsibility was placed on the Australian citrus industry. The onus of proof rested with that industry and an entire season's citrus crop faced totally unfair competition as a result. Furthermore, not only was the Australian citrus industry faced with this unfair competition and its growers savagely disadvantaged by it but also the Brazilians were advantaged. That is proved by the simple fact that anti-dumping provisions were subsequently brought against the Brazilian industry.

The second industry with which I have some familiarity and which has been involved in anti-dumping provisions is the wine industry, particularly the brandy industry. In speaking to representatives of the brandy industry this afternoon, I discovered that they are a little concerned because they are now required to resubmit their claim for anti-dumping provisions against the French only because of the movement in the exchange rate, which has been wildly fluctuating over the last 10 days.

The Opposition is not opposed to the legislation before the House but it has a number of real concerns, which have been expressed by previous speakers. One of the principal concerns has been that the Anti-Dumping Authority is being set up with a time frame that we believe is not tight enough to ensure that the disadvantage to Australian industries is kept to a minimum. We believe that the period of 70 days provided for an investigation should be reduced to 55 days and that the further period of 180 days to make a preliminary finding as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed ought to be reduced to 120 days in the interests of Australian industry. I restate the dilemma that Australian primary producers in particular face when an entire crop can be lost in the time it takes to prove that dumping has occurred and to have some sort of restitution implemented by way of anti-dumping provisions. We believe that that time ought to be kept to a minimum and that provision should be made for a faster form of fast tracking.
