SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to contribute to the debate on the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill. I will try to contribute from a somewhat different perspective to that of some of my colleagues. I certainly strongly support the comments made by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and the amendments that he will be moving. It is perhaps a useful exercise to step back a little from this process and these pieces of legislation and take a somewhat longer term view of what is happening in the area of protection under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably true to say that there has been a group of key Ministers who have got together and decided to re-assess this Government's position on the issue of protection. They have embarked upon a process which has three main aims: first, they recognise the need to cut protection more; secondly, they have decided that we need to be able to quicken the pace of those cuts in protection; and thirdly, there has been a fairly conscious attempt to make the whole pro- cess far less transparent than it has been in the past. In simple terms, they are developing an integrated strategy through various pieces of legislation that will, from their point of view, commit the Government to faster cuts in protection and effectively streamline the process of tariff reductions in this country. As such, it is an implicit recognition, if not in the case of some Ministers an explicit recognition, that some of their industry plans, although in the right direction, have cut protection too little, have promised to do it too slowly and have done it far too transparently.

If we look over various pieces of legislation of the last few months our attention is drawn to a number of stages in this process. A decision was taken soon after the last election to transfer control of the Industries Assistance Commission to the Treasurer and the Treasury, and that was then followed by the replacement of the old Chairman of the IAC by a new man, Greg Taylor, who is, of course, an ex-Treasury officer. The main thrust here, I guess, is to get the IAC out of the whole process. The IAC has played a very significant and transparent role over the years in the protection debate. But now it needs a new role, in the view of this group of Ministers. It is probably a role that will oversee the whole process of micro-economic reform under this Government. It is an implicit recognition, nevertheless, that we do not need the IAC to cut protection. We do not need its reports any more. In the days when it was difficult to convince people that protection needed to be cut, or that enthusiasm for increased protection needed to be restrained, the IAC had a very important role. It has outlived that role now, so why not give it something else to do? That was the first stage that is of some significance in the process initiated by this group of Ministers.

The second stage in this process was the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill, which really gave a lot of power to the Minister, with the approval of the Treasurer, to make amendments to the customs tariff Acts, that is, to vary the levels of assistance, without a policy inquiry and without a report from the IAC. This legislation was a sort of follow-up, in a sense, to that initial stage of significantly changing the role of the IAC. But it goes further in that it gives power to the Minister, with the cooperation of the Treasurer, to change the industry assistance levels in five specified circumstances without an IAC report.

As we said in the House last week, we do not have any particular problem with the first three of those circumstances, but the last two cause us some concern. Firstly, we are concerned that the legislation will work to overturn a decision of a court or tribunal. Secondly, and more importantly, we are concerned that it gives the Government power to change tariff rates in response to what were called `changes in economic conditions' affecting an industry. It is quite a significant power that enables a government to change protection without a reference to the IAC. But that sort of opportunity is consistent with the general picture that I am painting to the House.

Moreover, when we look at the legislation we see that, despite the use of the word `minor' in the explanatory memorandum and in the second reading speech, there is nothing proposed in the Bills that guarantees changes are minor. There is no limit on the size of any cuts or variations in protection and, as importantly, there is no longer any time limit on that process. It used to be the case that before it considered protection a government would have to get another IAC report if the current one was more than 12 months old. Under this legislation that would no longer be necessary.

The third stage in the process initiated by this group is the anti-dumping Bills that are before us today. Interestingly, a number of people seem to be misreading these Bills as to what they really do. The Bills basically make it more difficult to get trade restrictions on the grounds of dumping. They make it quite a lot more difficult. In effect, they give greater power to the Minister, as I read the Bills, to vary the level of protection-in fact, to withstand, in this particular case, unjustified claims for increases in protection on the grounds of dumping. A significantly greater onus of proof will exist under this legislation. Also Clause 12 of the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill gives the Minister quite a lot of power to make directions to this new Authority, which is a one person Authority. Apparently the Minister can also make directions to that Authority in terms of what he considers to be in the national interest.

From that point of view it is an interesting group of Bills in two senses; first, in the sense that the Minister is making it more difficult to mount a case for increased protection-on the grounds of dumping-and, secondly, in the sense that there are circumstances in which he can direct a new authority, which effectively replaces the IAC, to carry out his instructions. Of course, he is still subject to parliamentary scrutiny in those activities, as he is under the earlier Bills I mentioned. There will be parliamentary scrutiny down the track, but it will be an ex-post-scrutiny rather an ex-ante-scrutiny, as was the case in an IAC inquiry. There is no need for an inquiry any more. And of course this may not mean too much restraint if there is bipartisan support, and there now seems to be fairly widespread bipartisan support for accelerated cuts in protection.

Against this background, I am somewhat surprised at industry support for the idea of a new anti-dumping authority. Some of the comments I have read seem to suggest that industry feels it will now be somewhat easier for it to get decisions made in favour of increased protection on the grounds of dumping. I suggest to industry that that is not the case. In fact, from the way I read the Bills, it is probably only `predatory dumping' that would get through and would draw the attention of the Minister in this respect.

The fourth stage in the process which I am describing initiated by this group of Ministers, will come to us tomorrow in the context of the mini-Budget when we are told something more about further cuts in protection. There has been much debate about this matter and, to an outsider in this process, one can only be fascinated by the extent to which this Government has torn itself apart on the issue of tariff cuts. It seems pretty clear to my mind that we will see that this group of Ministers has been quite successful; they have probably got a commitment to top-down cuts in protection, perhaps a unification of the level of protection, at around 15 per cent-or perhaps even a little less-but they will probably bow in the direction of some of their concerned colleagues by excluding industries that are presently subject to an industry plan, or they might bow in the direction of the `classic' textiles clothing and footwear bogey man. My guess is that the process of cutting protection will be taken one stage further tomorrow with the decisions we will get in the mini-Budget announcing significant cuts in tariffs.

As I said, we now have a set of circumstances in which the Government can make much more substantial changes in protection than might otherwise have been the case. It can make them quicker and I think it can do them much less transparently than otherwise would have been the case. When we look at the package of measures I have described in those terms, we should realise that they probably deserve quite a lot of support for the general thrust of what they are forcing the Government to do. It reflects a recognition on its part-although not so widespread a recognition on the part of the Left or on the part of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-that past protectionist policies have been misguided.

It is probably also an implicit recognition that, while we as a country have put fairly strong cases, and have done so over many years, for multilateral cuts in protection, there is now the possibility as a result of these pieces of legislation that, if multilateral processes under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade fail to bring about the sorts of cuts that we might want to see in protection, there is now a capacity to go it alone, and at least there will be a capacity to move on a bilaterial basis. I was surprised and fascinated that, when Clayton Yeutter the United States trade negotiator was out here-although he was incorrectly quoted-apparently promoting the possibility of developing a free trade zone between Australia and the United States, nobody in the Government seemed to take up this suggestion and look at the possibility of that sort of development down the track. It seems to me that the need for more bilateral discussions at the trade level will be inevitable; even if we are likely to get substantial success out of the multilateral trade negotiations.

The Government seems also to have recognised that some of its efforts in labour market deregulation and so on will be particularly slow in coming to fruition. It now recognises that perhaps the best way to bring rationality into the labour market is to cut protection in the marketplace. Once we start cutting protection and exposing industries to the direct effects of international competition we will probably substantially quicken the process of deregulation in the labour market. Industries will find it much more difficult to renegotiate wage and labour market agreements which they feel have been to their benefit because they were negotiated behind very high levels of protection in the past. It would be much more difficult for them to negotiate such deals in the circumstances of a significant reduction in protection, particularly in some of the most protected industries where some of the most ludicrous wage deals, working conditions and work practice deals have been made in the past.

Whilst the Government's timing is a little late, considering the fact that our currency started to devalue significantly in 1985, it is still a good time to force the pace of cuts in protection. Devaluation, as the House would recognise, represents a significant increase in effective protection. As I said, while we are a little late in this process, it is probably still a good time to move. So we should encourage this key group of Ministers as much as possible to continue to cut protection. But in so doing we need to ensure that, in pieces of legislation such as this, and in the Industries Assistance Commission Amendment Bill which was dealt with last week, there were adequate safeguards to protect against the possibility of a shift within the Australian Labor Party-some members of the Left and, as I read recently, even some on the Right are concerned about the pace of tariff cuts-that might prevent a process of protection cutting from being reversed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In introducing the Anti-Dumping Authority Bill, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill, the Government, by various changes to anti-dumping legislation and by the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority, is puting in place streamlined procedures and less ambiguous guidelines for dealing with complaints of dumping. These changes arise from recommendations of the Gruen Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 commissioned by the Government in 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has consistently been a strong advocate of fair international trading practices and a supporter of anti-dumping measures. Our action in this respect is dictated to or circumscribed by our obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) anti-dumping code and some other agreements to which we are a party. Professor Gruen was asked to look at the matter in this light.

With this legislative package, the Government recognises that, whilst anti-dumping action has the potential to provide backdoor protectionism, unfair trading practices occur which are the very antithesis of free and healthy international trading and that the Government has no obligation to deal with this problem. Of the 167 dumping and countervailing duties in force at December 1985, more than a quarter had been in force for more than five years and more than half in force for more than three years. It is clear from this that anti-dumping measures have to some extent drifted into becoming protectionist measures and this is clearly not acceptable to the Government.

This tightening up of the anti-dumping procedure needs to be seen in the context of the overall program of industry restructure being undertaken by the Government. The Government has taken a hard look at the types of complaints being lodged at present and differentiated between those which, while they are obviously causing hardship, are not appropriately dealt with in this area. There will always be a grey area in determining what practices constitute dumping and what constitute free trade. Professor Gruen pointed out in his report:
. . . extensive use of anti-dumping action has the potential to frustrate the achievement of other government objectives in the industry, trade, competition and economic policy areas.

The Government has had to be very sensitive to this prospect in formulating its new policy. As a result of these concerns, this legislation in a sense narrows off the area to be considered for anti-dumping action in that these measures are aimed specifically at dealing with predatory and other short term dumping only. However, within this area it tightens up and strengthens government action. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has clearly signalled his intention to vigorously use his powers to impose retrospective duties to ensure that Australian industries are adequately protected from unfair trading practices. Other areas of industry policy either provide recourse for those whose problems fall outside this ambit or assist in restructure to enable them to cope on an efficient footing.

The legislation aims to ensure that dumping complainants have a fair go. If their complaint of dumping is not upheld in the preliminary investigation by the Australian Customs Service, or if there is a preliminary finding that no duty should be imposed, they have the right of review by the Anti-Dumping Authority. As far as such appeals are concerned, the Authority replaces the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) in its present role as the reviewer of dumping matters. If the IAC has an interest in dumping it occurs in relation to the long term problems of low priced imports, which is more correctly a question of industry assistance policy than one of dumping. Removing its function in relation to dumping clearly signals the division between the two and supports the Government's overall strategy in this respect. The intent in relation to this has been further signalled by the inclusion of a sunset provision. Under this provision, measures taken in relation to a particular episode of dumping are operative only for a maximum of three years. After this time, if the problem still exists the industry can apply to have the anti-dumping provisions reimposed, but this will be done only after the situation is completely retested.

Under this package the process for dealing with complaints will be streamlined in terms of both procedures and the time allowed for the report to be completed. The Customs Service retains responsibility for the initial investigation of a complaint and, for the first time, statutory limits have been placed on the time it has to do this. The legislation lays down that the Customs Service must determine within 70 days whether there is prima facie evidence for an investigation. If this is established, it has a further maximum of 180 days to make a finding as to whether duties should be imposed. If it finds in favour of the complainant, the matter then passes to the Anti-Dumping Authority, which examines the matter afresh.

On the face of it, this might still appear a cumbersome procedure. However, it is essential that there be a systematic and predictable method of dealing with each complaint. It is also important that Australian industries understand that they will not succeed with complaints launched in order to protect them from competition they cannot cope with for various reasons rather than competition which actually qualified as dumping. They will need to seek redress, if this is appropriate, in a different forum, such as the IAC.

Frustration with the delays and uncertainty experienced under the present system led to calls for retroactivity of duty imposition when a dumping case is proven, a course not possible in most cases if we are to adhere to article 11 of GATT. This was made clear when the Caucus industry committee looked at this point. Article 11 of GATT stipulates that, with certain exceptions, `definitive anti-dumping duty may be imposed only from the date of the finding of threat of injury or material retardation'. The Minister does have some room to move in this respect but, in considering retroactive duty imposition, he must look at the prior knowledge and intent of the importer and the extent and severity of the injury caused to the Australian industry before retroactive duty can be applied.

In general, anti-dumping measures are not intended to be punitive measures. However, the imposition of retroactivity clearly has a punitive result because time has passed and the goods have presumably been sold down the line so the producer would no longer have the option of adjusting prices as a result of duty payable. The intent of the GATT agreement is clearly that such a measure should be applied only in extreme circumstances and cannot be done as a matter of course.

This legislation makes a number of other important changes. It enables any affected party to lay a complaint. This means, for example, that producers involved in another stage of the affected industry-such as raw material producers-or employees or their unions can cause an inquiry to be initiated. This is important in cases where the actual industry is for some reason inhibited from laying a complaint. I am pleased to say that this has been specifically included because of deliberations by the Caucus industry committee following concerns expressed by my colleague the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). Under the previous legislation it was possible for affected parties to take action. However, this was not spelt out and was not widely known or used. A further inclusion at the representation of the Caucus industry committee is that the legislation now provides that an action may be initiated in anticipation of injurious imports. There will be no need to actually wait for the damage to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —That part is very important.
—That is right. This will work in combination with the imposition of statutory time limits to hasten a resolution and control damage.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation, in establishing the Authority, also provides the Minister with a small and responsive group of economic and commercial experts charged specifically with observing current government industry policy. Further guidelines may be provided to the Authority at any time by the Minister. This will ensure a much greater degree of responsiveness and flexibility than exists at present. In fact, this is the ideal mix-an input of on the ground expertise overlaid by a political perception from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially when he is such a good Minister.

—Precisely. One issue which Professor Gruen was specifically asked to look at in his report was the question of the possible inclusion of a national interest provision as a condition for the purposes of decisions to impose duties under sections 8, 9, 10 and 11 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. Such a provision could be broadly defined as placing an obligation within the process to look at the general economic implications, including the effects on other industries and on consumers. Professor Gruen recommended against such a provision and the Government has followed his advice. Broadly speaking, he felt that such a provision would muddy the water-that it would make the grounds for consideration of a complaint much more nebulous, thus creating uncertainty and increasing administrative procedures. He also believed that it would lead to intense lobbying on the Government on each individual case and militate against the ability to deliver a fast decision in the case of truly predatory dumping.

SPEECH.PARA: In this context it is true to say that the discretionary power given to the Minister gives him the scope to consider the broader issues at stake here and, clearly, when he is called on to exercise his discretionary power, such factors would be part of his deliberations. As well, as I have mentioned, the Authority is charged with the responsibility of taking note of Government industry policy in its decision-making processes. The net result is that there is the option, but not the obligation, to look at these wider issues in an explicit fashion.

The bottom line of the anti-dumping issue is that it is a sensitive economic and political issue, both domestically and internationally, and the factors which determine action can change quickly. Some decisions can be made only at the political level. For example, in the case of proven dumping, does the Government act in the same way if the dumped goods come from a country with which Australia has a large trading surplus as it does when we have a trading deficit? Because of factors such as these, final discretionary power has to remain in the hands of the Minister-as has been observed earlier, it is in safe hands-who can consider the interrelatedness of a number of prevailing trade and economic factors before making his decision. Nevertheless, the formation of the Anti-Dumping Authority, together with other changes in these pieces of legislation, gives him the best means of implementing policy in the fairest, most appropriate and most efficient method.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Anti-Dumping Authority Bill and cognate Bills which we are debating this afternoon are to amend Australia's anti-dumping legislation to implement some of the recommendations of the Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 that Professor Fred Gruen completed in March 1986, some two years ago now. Professor Gruen recommended that the present anti-dumping system be continued but said that the discrepancy in the concept of what he called unfair trade practices as it is applied within Australia and as it is applied by Australia to its imports of goods should be reduced. He also said that we should discourage a too extensive use of the anti-dumping system to restrict imports. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The anti-dumping system should not be used to shield import-competing industries from the necessity to adjust to longer term economic conditions . . .

I agree with those sentiments entirely. As consumers and business people, we in Australia can now participate in a sale, whether it be in Best and Less, a factory or whatever, and take advantage of the cheaper prices there. I think everybody in this country accepts that system and would welcome it. However, when it comes to buying cheaper goods on the overseas market, for some reason we often think that it is an evil thing. I admit that sometimes dumping is an inappropriate activity by overseas producers, but often all they are doing is offering their goods to us at a lower price and it is up to us to accept them or not. When we do not, that simply disadvantages buyers in Australia; it denies consumers within this country the benefits of those cheaper goods. We have seen many instances of that in recent years. One which comes to mind is when farmers were denied the advantage of buying fertiliser at a cheaper price because overseas countries wanted to sell their finished product to us at a cheaper price than it was produced in Australia. We have to be very mindful of these things before we rush into a lot of anti-dumping legislation, and I am pleased to see that the Government has taken many of those points into consideration.

Basically, the Bill proposes to set up what is called the Anti-Dumping Authority (ADA). This will be a statutory body to advise the Minister on policy guidelines, which will be developed by the ADA. The life of the dumping notices is to be restricted to three years. Also in the Bill is a proposal to prescribe the manner in which the Australian Customs Service (ACS) will conduct its preliminary investigations. The ACS will be required to conduct these preliminary investigations in such a way as to establish a prima facie case, it it thinks one exists, within 70 days and it will have a further 180 days to make a preliminary finding. Of course, the Customs Service can bring down a finding more quickly than that, but it can stretch it out to 250 days. Of course, this is very much removed from the fast tracking mechanism that is sometimes needed with anti-dumping legislation. I see that Canada allows only 90 days and the United States of America only 160 days.

Another thing that concerns me is something that the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) spoke about earlier, that is, some tariff levels will be able to be changed without reference to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). While I do not intend to expand on the comments which that honourable member made, I point out that the IAC has served us very well in this country and that I am very suspicious of that move indeed. The number of anti-dumping cases has reduced markedly over the past few years. In 1985 we had 285 cases being considered. That had dropped to 74 cases by 1 January this year. Even by 31 March only 35 cases involving 12 different countries were under consideration. Of course, that situation has come about mainly due to the savage devaluation of the Australian dollar and, to some lesser extent, to the downward trend in tariffs in this country.

I note that the Bill ignores Professor Gruen's recommendation for a complete rewrite of the anti-dumping legislation and also his recommendation for simplification in this area. The Bill also does not seek to repeal section 5 (9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, which sets out what is termed the normal value of goods. Gruen said that wherever possible a market-determined price should be used. That seems to be the logical way to go. Professor Gruen even suggested how this could be used for centrally planned economies that do not have a market-determined price. He said that if we used that, both in those economies and here, we could get a more accurate value than we do now. I am a little puzzled as to why the Government has rejected this because it would put any action in this area on a more accurate footing.

I note that the establishment cost of the proposed Anti-Dumping Authority in the first year is $1.2m and for each year thereafter $920,000. It will be made up of a secretariat of up to 16 persons. What pleases me is that the Authority will have to take into account not only any injury that will be caused to any Australian industry that makes a complaint to it but also a wider perspective. I think that is to be welcomed. The Authority will have to take into account things such as the general economic conditions in the country, whether any production difficulties will arise from its decision, and what domestic competition takes place in Australia. It will not be something that will flow through automatically from a complaint. I think that there are a number of points about dumping for which anti-dumping legislation is very valid. There has been in this country a need to determine who may actually initiate anti-dumping legislation. For example, if canned tomatoes were being brought into Australia by a subsidiary of an Australian company already canning tomatoes here, that may not affect the company canning the tomatoes but would affect the growers in this country. In times past growers have had difficulty in getting their case off the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens regularly.

—It does. I think there is also another area of concern which is much more difficult to legislate against. I refer to supermarkets, some of which in the past have coerced people who want to complain. They have said, `If you complain we will not stock your products on our shelves'. The people who have wanted to complain about cheaper goods coming into the country, which they believed to be coming in unfairly, have backed off from putting complaints before the Authority. That has happened not only in the case of growers but also in the case of food processors. I think that area needs looking at.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area of concern is the tariff duties applying to products coming into Australia in the case of people who say that they intend to make the products here as well. There does not seem to be a requirement of proof to show that such people really genuinely intend to make such products in Australia. There have been cases in the past of people saying that they intended to make in Australian agricultural lasers and liquid nitrogen containers, which are used in the artificial insemination industry. The tariffs went up, but the articles were never made in Australia. Unfortunately, the consumers had to foot the bill for the extra tariff. I think that area needs to be tightened up.

There is yet another area that I believe is quite ridiculous, whereby a small company making goods can claim protection even though it may affect only a very small percentage of the market. For example, the company may make only enough of the product in Australia to supply 5 per cent of the domestic market, yet it can force to be put on a tariff which would affect all the market. In fact, it could even double the price. I think that an excellent example of this was recently pointed out by the shadow Minister for primary industries, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), in regard to wool fabric. Wool fabrics in this country are grossly overpriced because of the tariff on them, which is running at a level of 40 per cent, would you believe! Yet countries to which we supply the raw product can buy it much cheaper. For example, Italy, Germany, Japan, Britain and the Soviet Union can buy it more cheaply. This is particularly so with the high quality, lightweight wool fabrics that are very much coming into fashion in the world today. I am talking about the cool wool fabrics that are used particularly in women's gear. A 40 per cent tariff is imposed on them when they come into Australia whereas the competitors, such as the synthetics or cottons, attract only the nominal tariff of 2 per cent. I think that is quite unacceptable.

We used to have two leading textile weavers in Australia. They have now merged into one and supply only part of the market. All that this high tariff has done is force up the price to Australian consumers and decrease the range available to Australian people, so the Australian consumer is suffering to quite an extent. Amongst those Australian consumers, the poor people and the pensioners in particular suffer, because the price of these goods puts them well beyond the reach of these people.

Of course, the manufacturers of wool products at the end of the day are also adversely affected. Tariffs have incredibly detrimental effects in this country. They simply raise import prices and bump up inflation and the cost of living, and this flows right through the Australian economy. The net effect of all of this is merely to shift labour and capital from efficient industries to less efficient ones; it leads to less overall trade, and a higher exchange rate and a lower standard of living for us all.

High tariffs shift jobs from one industry to another, from one occupation to another and from one region to another. There is no net gain of jobs from high tariffs; in fact, it is now shown that fewer jobs result from high tariffs. I hope the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will take the opportunity in his mini-Budget statement tomorrow night to make a substantial cut in tariffs. If he does so, I will warmly welcome that.

In conclusion, I say that, if that is done and anti-dumping measures are enacted in Australia on a proper and sensible basis and not used just as another protection measure, all industry will be able to start to compete in Australia on a fairer and more competitive basis, to the overall benefit of us all.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said, the legislation implements the Government's response to the Gruen Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. There is absolutely no doubt that, in the past, Australia has been used for dumping of various goods such as steel and, indeed, wire. As I said, I have a particular worry about cheap Asian cement being dumped in Australia to the detriment of jobs and, indeed, the construction industry within Australia.

I have a Blue Circle Southern Cement Ltd cement works at Berrima in my electorate, but it is not only because I have a cement works in my electorate that I take particular interest in and support this important anti-dumping legislation. Of course, we are all in favour of cheaper goods, but it is not always like with like. It is all very well having cheaper goods, provided they are of equivalent quality. For example, we hear a lot about cheap Asian cement that might or might not come into this country. There has been quite a lot about it in the papers over the past couple of months. With cement, especially the Asian cement, many people worry that it is not chemically compatible with the local aggregates, and it is very important that the cement that we use here be compatible. We worry that some of the cement that is being imported might not be used for the specific purposes for which it was designed.

One must also be sure that, within the fairly precise boundaries, the chemical and physical properties of the cement do not vary. There is a worry that some of the Asian cement that could be imported into this country does not meet the fairly strict requirements. It would not be very beneficial even if that cement were coming in cheaper, if it were not of the quality that we demand in this country.

There is currently a great excess of cement capacity overseas, especially in countries desperate for foreign exchange. This committee, of which I have been a member, was very ably chaired by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham).

One of the difficulties that unions and producers had in taking anti-dumping measures against the Asian cement that was being imported was that no action could be taken until a properly documented complaint was received by the Australian Customs Service, giving all the facts and giving evidence demonstrating the elements of export sales to Australia at less than normal value in the country of origin. Indeed, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) made reference to this when talking about citrus fruits. The complaint had to be made by a company or companies representing a major proportion of the Australian industry, and needed to be supported by the balance of the industry.

On receipt of the complaint, the Australian Customs Service undertook within 30 days to advise the complainant whether or not the complaint was properly documented. Then it took another 40 days before the Australian Customs Service would advise the complainant whether or not the complaint constituted a prima facie case warranting investigation. If the Customs Service decided that it did warrant investigation, it would issue a public notice. A further 40-day period would need to be allowed, and then a formal investigation would commence. Then, within 180 days of the commencement of that formal investigation, the Service would make a preliminary finding and would have another 120 days from that date to make recommendations to the Minister as to whether substantive anti-dumping measures could be taken. The point he was making was that the long time they would have to wait would mean that the damage would have been done before remedial action could be taken. I was very pleased to note in the Bill, as the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) mentioned in his contribution, that it will now be possible for complaints to be made before allegedly dumped or subsidised goods have arrived in Australia, where there is adequate knowledge that imports of dumped or subsidised goods are to arrive in volumes which will cause injury to an Australian industry. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend to the House the second reading speech of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). In the speech the definition of dumping, which is often confused with that of tariffs, is clearly set out:

Dumping occurs when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value in the country of export. Normal value is usually the price of like goods sold in the ordinary course of trade for consumption in the country of export.

The House must be very careful about `normal value' and the context of the expression `the ordinary course of trade'. We can get into discussion about establishing normal values and what constitutes the ordinary course of trade. Again in the second reading speech the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business talks in this way about dumping on the international marketplace:

Dumping is condemned internationally as unfair trading if it causes, or threatens, material injury to the industry producing like goods in the importing country. The remedy against dumping is the imposition of dumping duties which can be up to the difference between the export price and the normal value.

This sets out the problems that manufacturing industries in Australia face in establishing dumping claims. The problem in Australia is that, under these arrangements, if goods can be proven to have been dumped they will by then have been in Australia for a full year and will probably have found a niche in the market.

I turn to examples of two industries on which the dumping procedures have had a major influence. Farmers at that time, especially in Western Australia, were concerned that they were not buying the product at its best price. TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the amendments moved by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). It is important to keep those maximum periods for reporting in the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill because there will be occasions when it will be necessary to use the full time available. SPEECH.PARA: The 180-day period is set as a balance between the requirements to provide natural justice to all parties while ensuring that industry is provided with relief and trade is not disrupted in the interim. Before initiating the dumping complaint, the Australian industry will have had the advantage of time to prepare its case. Other parties, such as the importer and exporter, must be allowed time to respond and submit evidence which must be adequately considered and investigated before a preliminary finding is made which could profoundly impact on trade. The experience with legal challenges in the Federal Court to various procedural steps has confirmed that the provision of natural justice requires adequate allocation of time to the procedure.

I also submit that the new time limits generally accord with the approach in the United States of America, Canada and the European Economic Community. The period is set out in legislation in the United States and in Canada. In the case of Canada, for example, the times within which dumping investigations are conducted are almost identical. One can have an option of a 90-day period or a 135-day period plus a further 90 days. The crucial difference is that in Canada the independent tribunal commences its 120-day inquiry into injury and investigation after the preliminary determination-that is, at either day 90 or day 135-and not at the conclusion of the customs investigation; that is to say, the final determination of dumping on either day 180 or day 215.

A further critical difference is that in Canada each organisation looks at only one element of actionable dumping. Customs looks at dumping and the margin of dumping while the tribunal looks at whether the dumping has caused injury. In Australia's case, within 180 days the Australian Customs Service will finish its full analysis of both the dumping and the injury to the industry. It is then proposed that the Anti-Dumping Authority take an absolute maximum of 120 days to examine independently the total question of dumping, injury and causal link. In effect, this is an independent review appeal mechanism for industry or the importers. This time is not seen as excessive, given the importance of the task, and protection to the complainant Australian industry cannot be eroded because of the provisional measures which have been put in place.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 April, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Research and Development Legislation Amendment Bill arises from a review process, the results of which were presented to the Government in 1987 and in which the operations of the research and development program were examined and a number of amendments were suggested. In this Bill the Government has come forward with two significant amendments, one to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the other to the Industry Research and Development Act 1986. The amendments arose out of a technical review in 1987 of the 150 per cent concession for research and development. These amendments were foreshadowed in November 1987 by both the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). This Bill will implement the decisions resulting from the review. The amendments are designed to stimulate investment in research and development projects and to ensure that Australia obtains a worthwhile return for revenue-subsidised research and development. It is intended that the Bill will increase the effectiveness of the administration of the research and development concession by transferring those powers and functions of the Industry Research and Development Board presently provided for in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Industry Research and Development Act 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the main features of the Bill is that the discretionary powers of the Board will be extended to enable it to determine the eligibility of companies and projects seeking the research and development concession. The powers of the Board will be tightened to prevent exploitation of the research and development concession for other than intended purposes. The Government frequently uses the wonderful term `unintended outcome'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Serendipity.

—It is something like that. The legislation seeks to provide safeguards projects by requiring that to be eligible, projects have sufficient Australian content. Furthermore, revenue-subsidised research and development projects shall be exploited to enable them to realise their full commercial potential for the benefit of Australia. Those are nice words, although I am not sure how the Government intends to go about achieving that objective. Importantly-and this is probably one of the most significant parts of the amendment-small business will have greater accessibility to the tax concessions, as this legislation will enable the Board to register a wider range of research agencies. The contracted expenditure incurred by companies whose annual research and development expenditure is less than $50,000 will be extended, enabling a wide range of small business which would not otherwise be eligible to enter the area of research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, for the purposes of the tax concession the Bill establishes a new category of research body, a registered research agency, to replace the approved research institutes. The Bill also provides for joint ventures for costly or risky projects. The amendments will enable the Board to provide prior in-principle approval and subsequently to jointly register participating companies. Under this amendment the companies register will reduce the risk of unfavourable tax treatment further down the track.

Those changes certainly make research and development far more accessible to small business, one of the areas that have been heavily penalised in relation to research and development. It was not possible in the past to get a tax concession for more than the usual amount of expenses incurred and an organisation was certainly not eligible for the 150 per cent tax deduction until it had spent at least $50,000, which is well beyond the capacity of a wide range of small businesses. That measure is to be commended. The ability to go into joint ventures is also welcomed by the Opposition. This is an area in which I believe we will see a considerable take-up because ventures in the future are a risky business. One must make a judgment as to how far one can go. If a joint venture is properly constructed with research and development on one side and salesmanship and management on the other, there is no doubt that the outcome for those involved will be very beneficial.

The proposal to exend the tax concession to a new category of research body, the registered research agency, is also welcomed. This will enable a wide range of private enterprise research facilities to be used properly, probably on a wider scale. Many corporations in Australia run significant research laboratories, in some cases involving time lags in terms of use. I know of a number of corporations which have quite expensive set-ups and which would welcome the opportunity to contract out or contract in for work which may be supplementary or which might take up some of the down time which occurs in some private institutions. On top of that, I think the move away from the research institutes is a healthy way to engender some competition between the various institutes in Australia and private enterprise. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has made a valuable contribution over the years. Nevertheless, these days, with the wide range of scientific development that is taking place, it is very opportune to cross-fertilise with the private sector research institutions in Australia, some of which are of a very high quality.

The provision to ensure that projects have sufficient Australian content is worth while, but not of the greatest moment, I would have thought. The main thing is to get research work done in Australia rather than our having to buy the copyright to overseas research, which is expensive and sometimes involves a massive time lag. The discretionary powers of the Board are to be extended to enable it to determine the eligibility of companies for the tax concession. I think that is also a worthwhile step. It concerns me that the board of any institute such as this which has to make a judgment will inevitably be forced into making qualitative decisions which could well be wrong. I have only recently come by the 1986-87 report of the Industry Research and Development Board. The sand in the glass did not run too strongly when that report was being prepared. By the time it came to hand it was almost a year out of date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Budgetary restraints, you understand.
—I thought it was the efficiency of the Government which I hear so much about! In chapter 9 (1), under the heading `evaluation', the report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Board is required to evaluate the effectiveness of the operations under the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 and to report on this evaluation in each of its annual reports.
Hence my interest. The report continues:

The Board is of the view that evaluation of its operations and monitoring of the schemes which it administers are vitally important to its own ability to carry out the functions for which it was set up.

At this stage it is too early to comment on the effectiveness of the Board's operations against the broad objectives of the incentives. The Board will commence evaluation in 1987-88 and report in that year's Annual Report.

I hope that that report will come down fairly quickly because it is important to see how these sorts of schemes are operating. I know from the experience of the Executive Director of this organisation, who has had a very lengthy association with research and development and a good background with the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, that such matters will be considered to be most important in the future. The report continues:
The Government has requested the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) to undertake cost effectiveness reviews of the tax concession . . .

That is vitally important. Far too often these sorts of investments-and I am speaking here as an investor-are made on the basis of the tax concession rather than the worthiness of the project. An assessment of the worth of a project is certainly a matter of business judgment but there is no doubt that the tax concession is the all-important item to the investor. The report continues:
A large portion of the information on which the BIE will base its evaluations will be collected by the Board.
So it is important to address ourselves to the importance of the Board. Paragraph 9.1 continues:
This information will include:
information based on company registrations for the tax concession-in providing this information to the BIE, the board will preserve the confidentiality of companies;
information on applicants for grants under the GIRD scheme; and
information on the progress and success of individual projects supported under GIRD.
Under the heading `Future plans', it is stated:
Much of the Board's resources in 1986-87 were devoted to developing administrative arrangements for its responsibilities under the GIRD scheme . . .

The Board considers that it is now in a better position to undertake the ongoing administration of these schemes. It will, therefore, be able to place more emphasis on other activities designed to achieve its objectives. In particular, high priority will be given to the additional functions directed by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in June 1986, viz:
organising forums for the discussion and implementation of research opportunities-
they would certainly have their place-
ensuring adequate public awareness of IR&; and
fostering greater understanding and collaboration between Australian and overseas R& activities.
That is particularly important if we are to save ourselves some money.

Membership of the Board is one area in which the Opposition disagrees with the Government. It is proposed in clause 11 to increase the size of the Board from 10 members to 13. It strikes me that the 10 members of the Board are all competent people. I do not personally know all of them, but I know a number of them. I am aware that all the ones I do not know have held positions of significance and because of that their contributions would be valuable. On top of that, the secretariat, on the basis of the executive directors and others, seems to be made up of people with competence in the area. I refer to the Board committees. The Chairman of the Tax Concession Advisory Committee is a member of the Board, and a number of its members come from such places as Hungerfords and the well-known firm of solicitors, Barker and Gosling. Even an Assistant Commissioner from the Australian Taxation Office is a member of that advisory committee. That in itself would frighten most businessmen. Similarly, the Discretionary Grants Committee is chaired by a member of the Board, and he is assisted by people on the Board and from outside. It is the same situation with the Technical Qualifications Committee and with the Biotechnology Advisory Committee, the New Materials Technology Advisory Committee and the Information Technology Advisory Committee. So in all there are some six advisory committees and a board.

I have made observations before about government advisory committees in relation to company law. Some are very good and some serve a purpose, but undoubtedly there is a tendency for the secretariat to be the guiding hand in all their discussions, and because of the secretariat and the number of committees the Opposition fails to see why another three members should be added to the Board of 10. Thirteen is quite a large number. It is only half the size of the Federal Cabinet, nevertheless it is a sizeable number to run a business orientated research project. Thirteen members is too many; the current 10 seem to be performing adequately. In the committee stage we will be opposing clause 11.

I turn to the future of these research and development grants. For a very long time Australia has never had the companies with the capital base or the profitability to spend money on research and development. It has been a matter of record, and a matter of some regret, as well, that it has been far cheaper for companies to buy technology rather than spend money on it themselves. Until such time as Australian companies are bigger, more profitable and more research orientated this is likely to continue. Therefore, the incentive offered in this plan, which is a continuation of the previous Government's plan in a slightly different form, is welcomed, and I hope that industry will respond to it. We cannot sit back and continue to run business on the basis of franchising. Franchising means putting ourselves years behind the industry front. To accept that position is to condemn the nation to a secondary role in the technical and manufacturing areas. For that reason the Opposition supports the general thrust of the Bill. I wish it well, as I wish the secretariat and all the members of the Board well. We should all follow its progress, and certainly I look forward with great interest to reading the new report which will surely come out at a far greater pace than the last one. We support the Bill, except for the size of the Board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pleased to hear the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). I do not doubt the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) will explain in great detail the reasons for the extension to the Industry Research Development Board's membership. In supporting the amendments I would like to refer to the background of this legislation and the creation of incentive for research and development in Australia. We have all seen the figures indicating how poorly we have performed in this field, and we can all give reasons why this has occurred. The honourable member for Ryan suggested that capital base and profitability were factors, and they may well be. Frankly, I believe they are not the major factors. Our manufacturing industry, in particular, has tended to be derivative. We have tended to use licences, pro- cesses and procedures and even equipment developed in other countries to manufacture products strictly and solely for the Australian market. Market size was important, but we never looked outside the Australian population as a natural base. That meant, therefore, that we were investing in relatively small production volumes. It also meant that production was a mechanical, procedural matter rather than an intellectual, creative matter. In the process, of course, we tended to induce a high cost of production.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years we saw what was called `technology transfer'. That is a fairly ambiguous phrase which to some people meant we were doing well because we had modern technology and that we should therefore be proud of our achievements. We were producing things that were produced in some of the world's leading countries. That misnomer, that misuse of that terminology, I think did a great deal of damage to the psychology of Australian manufacturing because the perception was a very wrong one. The technology transfer that we perhaps exploited and developed for so many years was a form of aping. It was derivative. It was, essentially, copying. Our creative skills were being used to replicate products designed and manufactured elsewhere. I am fascinated by the number of times Australian ingenuity was used to modify products and production processes during the period. Licence holders were able, in many cases for no charge whatsoever, to have their product improved. They were able to use an improved version in their markets as a result of Australians looking for better ways of doing things. That whole psychology of the derivation of licensing crippled us for decades. One could have said, `Why do we not just stop licensing?'. That would not have worked, firstly, because the access to products would have taken a long lead time to develop.

In recent years a number of licensing companies have allowed Australian manufacturers to extend their market area. An oft-quoted example is the Ericsson company. It was supplying most of the Asian markets from Sweden. It was manufacturing in Australia, but the Australian product was not able to be sold out of Australia. Products from Europe were being sold to our neighbours. We were not allowed to supply those markets. Now Ericsson has extended the Australian capacity into the Asian region. That has been true of many other suppliers. The difficulty of addressing that matter in the timeframe that was available to us in 1983, in the context of a significant crisis in manufacturing, was fairly profound. Some can argue and have argued that the methodology of using the tax concession was very brutal and all-encompassing. Quite frankly, it was. The problems at that stage called for fairly brutal solutions.

These amendments are part of the process of making the legislation more sophisticated and refined. Clearly, there was a capacity for tax minimisation. So, rather than being used for the development of new products and new capacities, it was used simply to reduce the taxation payments from some companies. It was also difficult for companies with no research and development base to be able to take advantage of the concession, whereas the larger companies which had research and development staff or experience were able to move in and utilise this concession very quickly. Many of them did. The smaller companies found it much harder to use the concession. It also meant that a company had to be profitable.

Part of these amendments is directed towards the second aspect. The first aspect related to tax minimisation; the second related to the need to ensure that we accommodated the newer emerging companies so that they were able to invest in research and development. At the same time a problem arose as to what was research and what was development. How was it to be classified? The changes brought forward in the legislation, in terms of research agencies, will be fairly important. It makes the application much more flexible which, in turn, means a greater degree of monitoring.

Some, perhaps, will suggest that this legislation and these amendments will be cumbersome and difficult. That is totally unavoidable in the context in which we are working. We are trying to find a measure to accelerate massively an attitudinal situation in Australian manufacturing, to shift the focus away from just producing to learning how to produce and how to design. I am seeing this concession impacting on industries with which I am familiar. It is being talked about increasingly and mobilised increasingly. The results are gradually coming through. In the years to come we will see the results coming through much more significantly in our figures.

One would hope that over time our manufacturing culture will have absorbed this concession and adjusted company spending priorities so that research and development are a normal part of any company scene, and will be looking to design, to manufacture and to create rather than using licences. The sooner Australia is licence free-that is a long way away-the sooner we can start talking about being a genuine manufacturing country.

The honourable member for Ryan referred to this aspect in the context of where one is in the system. When a company manufactures under licence it knows that it is a long way from the front. Even without a licence it can still be well behind. Australia will increasingly be at the forefront of world manufacturing-not necessarily in the large volume items, or in the mass market sellers, the big products, but in the more sophisticated items, the small batch items, the items that require a higher and higher degree of manufacturing skill. This legislation will have an enormous impact of allowing us to bridge that gap, to make that transition.

From the Government's point of view it has been difficult to bring these amendments together in an appropriate form. I do not think anybody expected that it would have been easy. It is important that industry and the community at large realise that this concession is so vital. It had to be done as well as possible. I do not doubt that in the months and years ahead we will need further changes and fine tuning or refining. That is the way it should be. It would be quite pointless for us to expect to sit down and design such a complex process and to get it perfect from day one. We have to accept that, as it impacts on industry, industry will respond and there may be further need for fine tuning.

I hope that in the years ahead we will not need tax concessions for research and development and that there will be profitability within industries that will allow our capacity to use Australian brain power, skill and ingenuity to generate products that are appropriate to us and to the markets within our region. I hope that in the years ahead research and development will become a significant part of company priorities rather than being the last thing on the Budget and the first thing to get cut when a company runs into difficulty. I hope that in the years ahead it will be part of our manufacturing culture and psychology, that research and development will automatically be considered as the most vital part of any company's forward program. In that kind of future, measures such as this taxation concession should and will become irrelevant. How far away that future is, quite frankly, I would not like to predict. I believe that it is coming and I believe that this concession eventually will serve its own purpose in making itself redundant to a significant degree.

In supporting the amendments, it is important to place on record, and for government members who have worked with and are close to industry to convey to the Minister and to the Cabinet, the fact that industry is responding, that it understands this concession, that it appreciates it and that it is trying its best to make it work at its end.

Having been given the task of being the Minister's shadow, I know that it is a formidable task. SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is important to the development of science in this country. All of us, regardless of where we stand in this House, ought to be prepared to embrace it wholesomely because our future certainly is tied up with the success we will have in these fields.

As I said, we do not oppose the Bill. However, we propose to move an amendment which has been circulated by the honourable member for Ryan. It is an amendment to clause 11 which we oppose. Clause 11 effectively says--

I ask the Minister-I do not know whether he will have time to sum up, given that the Bill has been guillotined-whether the registered research agencies, referred to at page 3 of the second reading speech, relate to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and, more particularly, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO). Certainly by the time 1991 comes around, when the 150 per cent deductability comes to an end, we all hope that there will have been a major increase and that whichever party is in government will have to make a decision as to whether or not it will continue. One hopes that if the 150 per cent research and development deduction is not shown to be working extremely successfully in 1991 we will not take it away prematurely; rather, we will recognise the very important role it has played.
The Minister made some interesting points in his second reading speech. In order to refresh the memory of honourable members I will quote from page 8 of the speech:

The latest statistics suggest that, typically, Australian companies invest in research and development only half that of world competitive companies. Before the introduction of the tax concession it was a third. The progress of the last three years is encouraging but not sufficient.

It is important for the House to realise that, based on current information, that increase research and development is not sufficient. This is no time to be complacent, and that is partly why we support the Bill. We think there is a lot more work to be done, a lot more research and development to be done. We do not want to start walking away from the possibilities that research and development will bring to this country. At page 9 of the second reading speech an interesting point is made, and it relates to the point I made earlier about government instrumentalities involved in science:
There is a goldmine of commercial exploitable research in government funded research organisations and academic institutions.
Indeed there is. The speech continued:
There is no shortage of innovative ideas and enthusiasms in some of our smaller companies.

That is also correct. Those two areas-academia and research institutes such as ANSTO, CSIRO, and indeed the gene shear technology which comes from basic research that was announced by CSIRO recently-are the areas we need to be capturing. If it be that government should be there fostering, supporting and encouraging, I think that is a useful role for government to play. Some figures I have sought leave of the Minister to table later on in my speech show that Australia has a long way to go when measured against international performance.

However, not all has been rosy with the 150 per cent deduction. I am sure that the Minister would agree with that. A letter dated September which I received recently from KEL Aerospace Pty Ltd-I am sure that the Minister would be aware of the criticisms-makes this point:
It is a sad commentary on the 150% tax concession that so many top research managers could not understand the complexities of a scheme which was originally intended to assist Australian business.

If that is the case, perhaps we should be looking a little more clearly at how we approach industry with the details of this scheme. I know that some of the issues have been addressed since those comments were made. We ought to bear in mind that we do not want to get too complex about it. The Australian Scientific Industry Association, with its bulletin of August 1987, issued a Press release stating that it had campaigned and lobbied particularly hard for 150 per cent tax deductability for genuine research and development in industry. Finally, it was picked up by government, and we applaud that. At the end of the Press release the Association talked about the effect of imputation on that tax deduction and detailed where the problems were. It stated:
As it now stands, the 150% tax deductibility is nothing but a Government-sponsored fraud!

That is probably putting it strongly, but the point the Association was trying to make is that when the imputation effects are taken into account, the shareholders are the ones who are funding the tax deduction and it is not an offset against that company's tax liability. I notice that in Mr Fricker's Press release in September there was some response in terms of seeking further details about Australian Taxation Office rulings and the draft Industry Research and Development Board guidelines on how to judge whether research and development activities are so considered for tax purposes. Some of those issues may have been picked up, but I make the broad point that there has been some disquiet among the possible recipients of those grants in that they want a more streamlined approach and less complexity. They want to ensure that they benefit when one takes into account the impact of the imputation system.

I now make a broader point regarding research and development which concerns Australia's role in that area. When I looked at the first report of the Industry Research and Development Board, which this Bill is all about, I was struck by what appeared at the very beginning. As someone once said in a song, the beginning is a very good place to start. The very first sentence reads:
We were struck by what seemed to be a widespread Australian view of technology as in some sense external to national life.

That was the examiner's report from the 1986 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) review of national science and technology policy. Mr Justice Gordon Samuels, who is the Chancellor of the University of New South Wales, with which the Minister now has some direct connection, said:

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table shows that Australia is falling behind in the research and development stakes because our levels of gross expenditure on research and development as a percentage of gross domestic product compared with other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries show that we are behind. If one is to measure a country's innovative capabilities by the level of business spending on research and development then, as shown in this table, expenditure on research and development by the Australian business sector has been extremely low. Consequently, one would believe that the level of product innovation also has been low relative to that of other countries. I think that tells an interesting story.
