SPEECH.PARA: One of the other interesting background papers produced by the Government, apart from, of course, the report entitled Improving Australia's Competitiveness Through Industrial Research and Development by the Australian Science and Technology Council in November 1987, is one that does not seem to have received a great deal of coverage by the media, which at times seem to like to fix on the sensational in research results but are, perhaps, less inclined to recognise their extreme importance. I refer to a report by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce entitled Measures of Science and Innovation. That report is extremely useful in that it canvasses some of the broader issues of Australian research and talks about the number of engineering students and science students.

It is interesting to note that here in Canberra we have the problem that those people who are to teach the teachers how to teach science are not actually enrolling in the science courses. So there is a growing problem. The National Science and Technology Centre going up across the road from Parliament House may help in some small part to redress that situation. However, there is a lack of interest in science at the very vital level of teachers wanting to teach science. I do not know how we make science more attractive, but certainly when one considers its importance and reads this particular paper one can see that we need to give attention to that issue.

I said that I would refer to a particular matter that focuses on some of the problems which we have suffered in scientific industrial research and development. It relates to the beta-carotene saga and the giant Swiss chemical company Hoffman-La Roche. The matter was subject to much Press speculation and a full review by the Bureau of Industry Economics found the whole arrangement with regard to the grant involved wanting. I do not think it is necessary to go into a lot of detail here but this was a prime example of a total mess-up.

Some $6m-odd of taxpayers' funds eventually benefited a Swiss multinational-not that I have total objection to that. I think that the research was important work. However, it involved a section 39 grant and it was used to fund research in direct competition with privately funded research. I understand that the section 39 grants have now been reviewed. Certainly the method of awarding them has been reviewed. I think that section may actually have been taken out of the Act. I can see the advisers to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business nodding in agreement.

The whole matter was a fiasco. I have no doubt that the matter has not been finalised yet. I have made constant calls for an investigation. I am still of the view that such an investigation ought to take place-not that we ought to go on a witch-hunt but that we ought to make sure that we do not fall into the same trap again. What I think has happened is that the Minister's enthusiasm, which is undoubted, has got away from him and perhaps he has been let down by some people in his Department-not that he is the type of Minister who would blame his Department. In any event, there have been some lapses and this whole sorry saga that ran for several years has meant that the good research that was done is now vested in a multinational company operating here in Australia.

I understand that there may well have been a domestic company that could have stepped in right at the beginning and benefited from the research. The Bill should ensure that such research dollars as are provided, whether by way of tax deduction or directly from government, benefit Australian research in Australian companies. What happened in this instance is the type of thing we do not want to happen. Making freedom of information requests is an interesting exercise for a politician but at the end of the day what is important is that it does not happen again and that we make every effort to ensure that both at ministerial level and at departmental level we avoid those sorts of problems. Really it is only a product of over enthusiasm and an intention to try to do the right thing. I make those critical comments in that vein.

I think that is all I need to say on this Bill. We support it, apart from the proposal with regard to the number of Industry Research and Development Board members. I reiterate that research and development are important. Those people who read the Hansard and look at the incorporated table carefully will know that there is a continuation of commitment from those on both sides of the House to research and development. The benefits that can accrue to Australia are immense. At a time such as this when we are suffering an economic crisis in terms of our balance of trade, we need to make every post a winner. I certainly hope that the Board continues to go from strength to strength. Certainly, as Opposition spokesman for science and energy, I will be watching this with extreme interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of the Research and Development Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, I want to take the opportunity to convey to the House my concerns regarding the calls for increasing development from members on both sides of the House in seeming disregard of the consequences of doing so. I am one of those Australians who have a strong belief in the Gaia hypothesis. In the words of James E. Lovelock, the originator of the Gaia hypothesis, this is the scientific view:

SPEECH.PARA: the entire range of living matter on the earth, from the whales to viruses, can be regarded as a single entity, capable of manipulating its environment to suit its own needs.

I would like to make it clear that there is nothing in this Bill which runs contrary to the Gaia hypothesis provided that it is appreciated that, since the advent of the Industrial Revolution, industry has significantly altered major chemical cycles of the earth. For example, the carbon cycle has increased by 20 per cent, the nitrogen cycle by 50 per cent and the sulphur cycle by more than 100 per cent. We have also increased the flow of toxins into our air and water and into our food chains.

With the increasing millions of human beings being added to the world population each year, all demanding the living standards and energy use of the people of the developed nations of the world, we will need to call a halt to the population and degradation of our planet resulting from uncontrolled development. I am not suggesting that we should sit like Luddites with a back to nature campaign. I am saying that we need to achieve a technology that recognises that the resources of our planet must be in harmony. For example, it is no good replacing coal fired power stations with nuclear power stations in order to get rid of the toxic sulphur dioxide emissions of coal fired stations when the replacement nuclear power stations produce radioactive wastes which remains toxic for thousands of years.

For those honourable members who are interested in the development of the resources of our planet in a sustainable and balanced system, I suggest that the Gaia Atlas of Planet Management, edited by Norman Myers, with contributions from many distinguised and eminent scientists, makes interesting reading. I know that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, would have read that atlas. I take the opportunity to congratulate the Minister on his honorary doctorate, which was well deserved.

Only last week Senator Bob Collins circulated a paper advocating an expansion of uranium mining in Australia. There are a number of assertions in the paper which I will challenge in an appropriate later response, but I was interested to read Senator Collins's comments about the various environmental problems of coal fired power stations. I agree with him wholeheartedly on the seriousness of this problem. I would anticipate that the main provisions of the present Bill, namely to increase the effectiveness of the 150 per cent tax concession in stimulating research and development by industry in Australia, will encourage corporations such as the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the State Electricity Commission of Victoria to expand their research into reducing the toxic emissions of coal-fired power stations into the atmosphere. The Gaia Atlas also refers to the problem. I quote from page 116:

Carbon dioxide is now increasing slowly but steadily. When we started to burn fossil fuels on a large scale with the onset of the Industrial Revolution, we caused a great deal of ``locked up'' carbon to be released; and this trend is now being aggravated by our burning of tropical forests. Whereas the level of carbon dioxide in 1850 amounted to 265 parts per million it has now grown to 340 parts and unchecked it would well reach 600 by the year 2050. The result is a steady warming of our planet, projected to rise by a mean 3*c above normal within the lifetime of our children. While there will be little change at the Equator, the poles may well become 7*c warmer with all this ultimately implies for the ice caps.

The difficulty I have with Senator Collins's paper is that, after correctly drawing attention to the emission problem of a 1,000 megawatt coal-fired power station, he then claims-and I quote-`A nuclear power station produces none of the above'. This statement completely ignores the serious hazards of radioactive wastes, both high level and low level. I quote again from the Gaia Atlas, page 125:

Twenty seven years (now 30 years) after the first commercial nuclear reactor began operating, there is still no acceptable solution to the problem of radioactive waste. Used fuel rods can be re-cycled to recover uranium and plutonium. But this process still leaves highly radioactive wastes to be disposed of. It is possible to store this waste in glass or turn it into synthetic rock but there is still considerable argument over the effectiveness of these processes. Other radioactive wastes include the tailings from uranium mining and nuclear power stations that have been `mothballed or shut down'.

The point is that both-coal fired and nuclear- powered stations produce serious toxic waste problems, and parliamentarians should not be advocating the expansion of either type of power station until the waste problems are solved. In fact, my research assistant, Chas Collison, and I produced in January 1986 and January 1987 a joint paper on radioactive wastes and nuclear accidents, which we entitled `The Unresolved Problems of the Nuclear Industry'. I recommend it to all members of this House and, indeed, to Senator Collins, who apparently has not read it.

Research and development into solving the problems of land and water degradation is another area where I hope the present Bill can aid primary industry in the attempts of many local authorities and primary producers in solving the serious degradation of our soil and water resources. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, of which I am Chairman-it is a good committee; the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) is also a very active member of it-has recognised these problems and has begun an inquiry into land degradation in Australia, with the ultimate aim of searching out possible solutions.
I would like to quote again from page 40 of the Gaia Atlas because it sums up the threat of erosion so well:

There is no known way that we can replace our soil. If we wait upon natural processes, we shall wait for centuries, if not millenia. The disappearance of our soil threatens to undermine our agriculture, our very means of supporting ourselves. Yet because it is such a cryptic and `silent' problem, few of our leaders give it a fraction of the attention it deserves. It is hard to whip up public opinion about the issue. Europe, the continent least affected by erosion, is estimated to be losing close to one billion tonnes a year, while Asia, the worst affected, could be losing around 25 billion tonnes. The US have well over one billion tonnes a year (net of natural replacement) from its grainlands-equivalent to more than 300,000 hectares of crop-growing potential.

A similar sad tale can be told around the world. I was interested to read in the March-April issue of the Athena magazine of one technological solution which, had it been promoted by industry in Australia, could well have qualified for support under the present Bill. The new technology has been developed under the Kallidendron method. Professor George Kallistratos of the University of Ioannina has perfected the method and, since dendron means tree, the method has been described as Kallidendron. The method is suitable for infertile soil in arid areas, including deserts. A mixture of 10 litres of perlite and 100 to 200 millilitres of a water absorbing polymer such as Evergreen-500 is mixed with peat, perlite, ashes, organic and inorganic fertilisers and placed in a plastic bag of 50 litres volume for fruit trees and 200 to 300 litres for larger trees. The bag is perforated to enable the growing roots to spread out of the bag into the original soil and then, together with the tree, is buried in the selected area.

I have given only a brief description of the kallidendron system, and there are obvious problems involved in the watering of the trees once they have become established. In the short term, artesian wells can provide the water but, with the low annual rainfall and high evaporation of arid and desert land, we have the problem that the artesian water will diminish in future years. In consequence, the creation of water reserves for the trees and methods to restrict the intense evaporation are being investigated by research workers. Water pollution is another serious problem area on which urgent research is needed. Diseases from water breeding insects, mosquitoes in particular, and water based and water borne diseases are serious killers of human beings. Water washed diseases such as trachoma infect some 500 million people each year, and defective sanitation is another killer, causing fatal intestinal illnesses in children.
Finally, in the little time I have been allocated, I would like to mention the serious pollution caused by lethal chemicals. I would like to quote again from page 122 of the Gaia Atlas:

Our planetary environment is a closed system. Persistent materials pumped into the air, dumped in rivers and seas, or hidden from view in landfills, do not simply melt away. The waste by-products of our industrial processes are a growing threat-sometimes an international threat.

The developed world regularly exports to the Third World hundreds of millions of kilograms of potentially lethal chemicals-chemicals classified as too dangerous for use in their country of origin. The irony is that these same chemicals (especially pesticides) return to the developed world on bananas, coffee beans, tomatoes and other foodstuffs imported from the developing nations.

The investment in research and development which the Research and Development Legislation Amendment Bill will assist will stimulate investigation into the problems which industrial processes are causing with the pollution caused by chemical wastes in the soil and in our water. I support the Bill and, as this is probably my last speech in this historic chamber, it is most relevant to draw attention to the serious problem which unplanned development can cause to Australia and to our environment.

I take this opportunity of thanking all the staff who have helped to make this Parliament so effective and who have also provided so much hard work in supporting the efforts of members in this House to represent their constituents. As I say, this is probably the last opportunity I will have to do that; and I want to ensure that I thank not just the people who help us so much here in the chamber but all of those who help to make this Parliament one of the most effective parliaments in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —In beginning my speech, I also would congratulate the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones)-who was my erstwhile opposite number when I had the task of being shadow Minister for Science and Technology-on the Doctorate of Science that he received from the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science. Well deserved.

SPEECH.PARA: I very much want to say a few words about the Research and Development Legislation Amendment Bill. It is very important. It focuses on the so-called 150 per cent tax concession for research and development. That is, indeed, a most important direct incentive to encourage industrial research and development-especially `development' which may be defined along the lines as, the translation of scientific research and innovative ideas into actual industrial technologies, hopefully leading to profitable job-generating businesses, sometimes entirely new industries, but more often and more importantly having the effect of furthering structural change and upgrading, revitalising and renewing existing industry. The overall area of research and development is the part where Australia's performance has been and still is lagging, that is, in the area particularly of private industry research and development especially-the translation of innovative ideas into actual technologies and the development of new job-generating industries.

I cannot forbear in this connection from pointing out that the proposal for this tax incentive was a key initiative of Liberal-National Party policy in the run-up to the 1984 election for which, I might say, as the then shadow Minister for Science and Technology, I was largely responsible. I am pleased that it has been implemented by this Government, and I believe the statistical record shows that it has been successful in lifting industry's technology and development performance.

The measure before the House attempts to refine the proposal and prevent improper exploitation so far as that can be done. The thrust of the Bill is to extend the discretionary powers of the Industry Research and Development Board to enable it to determine the eligibility of companies and projects to participate in the scheme and thereby reduce the incidence of companies being required to reimburse tax benefits. Its thrust is also to restrict the tax concession from being exploited in ways other than those intended, as I mentioned. That includes ensuring that pro- jects have sufficient Australian content and that the results of revenue-subsidised research and development are exploited on normal commercial terms for the benefit of Australia.

Further, it increases the access of small companies to expert research and development resources by enabling the Board to register a wider range of research agencies which can be contracted to conduct eligible research and development for companies. It also enables firms to participate in joint ventures for costly or risky projects.

So it is an important measure, particularly, as I say, in addressing the situation in Australia where private industry research and development lags. In the area of scientific research and innovative ideas Australia stands up well in international terms. The statistic is sometimes quoted that Australia, with about 0.3 per cent of the world's population, produces about 2 per cent of the world's science, quantified in terms of the internationally recognised scientific papers, that is an excellent ratio of output to population. The translation of such scientific research and innovative ideas into new industrial technologies and the effect on industrial development, employment and so on are where the lag has been and still is. One quantification in that area is that compared with the 2 per cent of world science we have about 0.7 per cent of world patents. At all events there is enough every day information to make that point plain.

There are undoubtedly constraints on this sort of activity in Australia, including in particular the small scale of the Australian economy and the very high cost of developing new products and processes. While those constraints are very real, they are not decisive, as experience in smaller countries overseas indicates-and indeed, to some extent, as our own experience indicates, if we go back far enough. In the 1960s and up to the early 1970s, industry expenditure on research and development was in the order of 0.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). That is not startling; overseas the percentages are one per cent or 1 1/2 to 2 per cent in this area as distinct from government-financed research. Nevertheless, that is better than the performance in recent years. I would lay the blame at the feet of the Whitlam Government back in 1973-74 when a variety of measures adversely impacted on manufacturing industry. There was the massive increase in government expenditure, inflation, and costs and various other factors, including the strong appreciation of the Australian dollar; manufacturing industry took a strong downturn. Only in recent years has there been a significant recovery, but still only to the order of about 0.3 per cent of GDP.

What needs to be stressed in that regard is that it is not such direct measures as this tax incentive that are important and other such government interventions as the management and investment companies program. What is also important is the overall economic climate. If the overall economic environment is not right, there will not be a healthy, flourishing industry or the type of development I am talking about. Industry research and development, new business investment and growth in a dynamic economy all flourish together. It is important that such specific measures as this and the other measures I referred to are implemented in the context of a flourishing, growing and dynamic economy. In this economy we are still plagued with high inflation, rising costs, interest rates that are still very high by international standards, and taxation rates for individuals and companies that are too high. We may hear something about company taxation tomorrow night. All these factors threaten our international competitiveness where we have relied, particularly for improvement, on the devaluation of the Australian dollar, but that, of course, has been creeping the other way.

In terms of those requirements, the importance of a strong reduction in government expenditure tomorrow night cannot be stressed too much. That would take some of the heat out of the real economy as the Government takes up less, and would take some of the weight off monetary policy so that interest rates would not have to rise to counter the overheating of the economy and also avoid the effect of maintaining too strong a capital inflow and the continuing appreciation of the dollar. In this context the policy required is not just a so-called science and technology policy; what is important is getting the overall situation right, and instituting other important reforms such as a reduction in business taxation-I say again, we may hear something tomorrow night-changes in depreciation schedules, changes to the inflexible and restrictive Australian wages and industrial relations system, reducing the profusion of regulations in our economy and so on but there can be no doubt that this specific measure, the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development, is also very important.
We are under the guillotine in debating this Bill, and to enable the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) to address the House briefly, I shall finish at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to choke off the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), but it was necessary for me to reply to a couple of the points made by the Opposition, particularly the proposed amendment. I thank the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) and the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) for their contributions. I was touched by the graceful references to my DSc honoris causa conferred by Macquarie University at the opening of the centenary Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Congress last week. I very much appreciate the references.

SPEECH.PARA: There was some concern about the expansion of the membership of the Industry Research and Development Board from 10 to 13. The impression was created that it was a wretched excess, but there are very sound practical reasons for it. Since the Board was originally established with its 10 members in July 1986 it has been given additional functions by the Government. Four generic technologies are now declared; there is a national procurement development program, the promotion of research and development generally, and also additional tax incentive functions. Those new functions mean a need for more expertise on the board, a need for a proper balance concerning members' talents and backgrounds.

In addition, in order to avoid any attempts to rort the system, the 150 per cent tax incentive has created much more work in the certification than was envisaged. The Industry Research and Development Board wants each committee to have two board members, one to chair it and one to back him up. There may not be always full board membership which makes back-up difficult when someone is overseas or otherwise engaged. With a busy board, that often happens. There are now seven committees which are involved with tax concessions, discretionary grants, biotechnology, new materials, information technology, communications technology and national procurement development. I think a strong practical case could be put for increasing the number from 10 to 13 simply to make it work. In some cases, it is going to be necessary to have a deputy of some sort to stand in for people who are unable to attend. If these people are not there, the work, of course, just does not get done.

A couple of other matters were raised. The honourable for Bass was concerned about the registered research agencies (RRA) which are to be set up. He asks specifically whether the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) were eligible for it. The answer is yes, they are. These registered research agencies replace the approved research institutes for the purpose of the tax incentive. These RRAs will be registered in respect of specific technology or technologies where the Industrial Research and Development Board considers that they are competent. So one can imagine CSIRO being registered perhaps in 20 different areas and DSTO in a different number of areas.

Registered research agency names and specific technological fields will be made public to provide companies with a reference when they need specialist help. As is the case with all organisations of excellence in research and development, CSIRO, ANSTO and DSTO would receive registered research agency status on application to the board. But they do not replace the approved research institutes for other purposes such as the receiving of donations and other kinds of scientific research.

The honourable member for Bass also mentioned the celebrated story of the section 39 public interest grant for the algal biotechnology project. Looking back on that project, I think I would have to apply what Senator Evans described in another context as the streaker's defence-`it seemed a good idea at the time'. There is no doubt that the recommendation of the advisory board created by my distinguished predecessor was not only unanimous but also extraordinarily enthusiastic. There is no doubt that if it had worked out as had been originally intended we would all be applauding the wisdom and foresight of the Government. We are very anxious that the community get a proper return from that investment.

The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has recently advertised in the national Press seeking expressions of interest from companies wishing access to the intellectual property from the project which remains with the Commonwealth Government. The aim of the Government is to give Australian industry access to the technology for development for the benefit of Australia. I still have some hope that this project will be a successful dollar earner with considerable export potential. Expressions of interest are currently being considered with a view to licensing companies as soon as possible to use the technology.

I know that the honourable member for Dunkley, if he were able to do so, would wish me to say that we have had many lost opportunities in the past. He is particularly concerned about the bad old days of the 1950s when the government of the day decided that computing did not have a future and told CSIRO not to do it any more; and the celebrated interdepartmental committee in Canberra in 1955-56 which said that transistors had no future and that we ought to put all of our public resources into the electronic valve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is absolutely essential to our nation.

—As the honourable member for Herbert says, they are absolutely essential to our nation. But we have been very slow in our recognition. Sometimes our response has been glacially slow. But I am glad that there are a whole number of areas in which there is genuine bipartisan approach. I commend this very important Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight actually to speak in support of the Government's amending legislation, the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill 1988. I do so in my capacity as Opposition spokesman in this chamber for arts and the environment. The Opposition has considered this Bill in some detail and has decided that it will not oppose it. The restructuring of Film Australia, which is the Government's film making body which specialises in the production of material, films and videos and departmental training and education films, follows the report of a review group which reported back in January 1987. Interestingly, this report was mentioned in last year's May statement, but it has taken 12 months finally to get the legislation into the House. One would wonder why it has taken so long to introduce this legislation and I am sure that in summing up the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) will have an explanation. But we have been sitting and waiting for some time for this legislation finally to come before the House. Perhaps in the knowledge that it was being supported by both sides, it might well have been opportune to bring it forward a little earlier. In any event the legislation is now before us. We see some advantages in the legislation and that is why we are supporting it.

SPEECH.PARA: We welcome the removal of the specific film making role of the Australian Film Commission as this will force the Commonwealth to concentrate on matters related to its promotion and distribution of Australian films. We hope that this move will also open the field of departmental training and government educational films to the private sector. Indeed, I think that is probably the intention of the Minister in this legislation.

Obviously the Minister would be anxious to tell us, but we might have to wait until tomorrow night to see what is in the May statement, about films this year. We would like to know-and the Minister can give us a preview if he likes-what is going to happen in respect of financial support for the film industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, okay!

—I thank the Minister-he is going to get it. It is interesting to note that in the Bill we have just dealt with, the Research and Development Legislation Amendment Bill, we were talking about a 150 per cent deductability for research and development for industry. I say that by way of a related comment. The film industry took a massive dive when the 150 per cent tax deductability on films was removed, and I will make some more comments about that. But when one can identify an industry which is of benefit to this country it is important that one does not prematurely take away support. I am sure that the Government will come forward with proposals to support the film industry, to redress the imbalance that has now quite alarmingly crept in and left the industry in a state of crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, for all its bluster, the Australian Labor Party is not the great film industry friend that it makes itself out to be. As I have said, the film industry has gone downhill and it really is in a crisis situation. It will be up to the Minister, even though he is a new Minister, to correct the mess that he has inherited from his predecessors. At the moment there are only four projects in production compared with 64 this time last year. That is a massive drop in activity in the film industry. This obviously has effects on employment but, more importantly, it has effects on what is a very important industry to Australia. The Minister knows, as do other members of the House, that in 1984 figures-and I do not quote with extreme accuracy-the value of this industry was, I understand, somewhere in the vicinity of $250m. So it would be worth a lot more if it was still going at the 1984 level. The level of film industry funding has dropped from $140m to under $40m in the past year as a direct result of the Government's policies and inactivity. There have been no new starts on major productions in 1988.

A new 20 per cent sales tax on the production of videos and sound recordings is about to commence. Perhaps the Minister for the Arts and Territories can give some details as to the expected impact of the sales tax impost and whether or not he has taken into account the calculation of that impact in proposing his new incentives, which will probably be announced tomorrow night. The so-called new initiatives and film proposals that we were told of in March this year have still not arrived. If the gestation period takes as long as the drafting of amendments to this Bill, we could be waiting another 12 months before we finally see some action. I hope that that is not the case. Really what we need from the Minister, being as young as he is-says this sage old man-is a little more action and a little less rhetoric.

I will make some comments about the history of the film industry, because I think it is important to have that in mind when the House considers the particular issues involving the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill. The Commonwealth's first direct involvement in film production occurred in 1911 under the aegis of the Department of External Affairs. In 1913 a Mr Bert Ive was appointed to coordinate Commonwealth film activities. In 1921 film was placed under the responsibility of the Cinematic and Photographic Branch of the Development and Migration Commission. Thereafter, during the war years, film activities were controlled by the National Film Council, Department of Information. The National Film Board took over after the war and the Film Production Unit took over in 1950. The Commonwealth Film Unit came into being in 1956 and continued until 1972. In 1972 Film Australia was established within the Department of the Media. Thankfully, we no longer have a Department of the Media; we are now beyond that stage.

In 1972 the halcyon days of film finally reached Australia and we embraced it with a vengeance. In 1975, with the passage of the Australian Film Commission Act, Film Australia was placed under the Australian Film Commission (AFC) as the production division responsible for the special activities of the Commission. In January 1987, as I said earlier, a major review of Film Australia was presented to the Government. The review canvassed four options, ranging from a complete closure of Film Australia through to the establishment of Film Australia as a more economically efficient operation focusing on the production of both departmental films and films of special national significance. In this legislation the Government proposes `option four with knobs on', according to Ms Robin Hughes, Film Australia's General Manager. Under the legislative provisions, and I have mentioned some of them, the AFC will no longer have the function of making major films and television productions. It will become a promotion and distribution body only, and this role becomes exclusive to Film Australia. The Bill also effects transfers to Film Australia of specified assets, liabilities and staff.

I will now deal with staff because I think that that issue has caused some concern. Indeed, it is of some immediate concern because, interestingly, in the Herald yesterday, Monday, 23 May, there is an article headed `30 face sack in federal film plan'. The article goes into some detail and quotes members of the Australian Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association, who talk about their concerns. The article also refers to the General Manager of Film Australia, Ms Robin Hughes, as follows:
. . . offers would be made to those employees they would like to transfer to the company-
which this Bill creates-

others would be offered positions within the Film Commission, and the rest would be offered voluntary redundancy packages . . . Ms Hughes said the re-structuring was necessary `in order to operate as part of the industry rather than as part of the Public Service'.

I think that that is probably a commendable position. Perhaps the Minister, when addressing these staff issues which I think are important, should spell out a little more clearly than I can pick up in the preliminary guidelines he has provided whether or not these employees will come under the aegis of the Public Service Act.

One point that I want to make in reference to staff is that we have been waiting for 12 months for this to happen. I do not know why there has been such a long gestation period. If we are now going to see the revamped Film Commission, the company, begin with a strike, that is hardly an auspicious start. I hope that the Minister will take into account the fact that he must do something quickly to forestall any repeat of the comments and headlines we have had. All honourable members want this to work, so headlines such as those to which I have referred require the Minister's attention. Perhaps the Minister could also respond to the question of the Public Service Act.

Some questions remain with respect to the guidelines as settled by the Minister. What is the consultation process proposed for the staff director? In view of the industrial action I have just mentioned, this will be important, but we must not let the staff director be the power, which seems to have been the case in the past with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Perhaps we could have some detail as to how the Minister will make that determination. Interestingly, the Minister's guidelines state that the staff appointee to the board of directors, and I think there is to be only one, will be a suitable nominee, and that person is to be chosen by the Minister. However, if they have all been on strike, how will the Minister determine who is a suitable nominee? Perhaps the Minister can tell us what is meant by `a suitable nominee'. Obviously this has been drafted with care to provide the Minister with some flexibility, but I am sure that in addressing the staff issue the Minister will have to do so to their satisfaction.

In relation to the power proposed in the articles for the Minister to appoint and remove directors, one does not need to go back very far to see what occurred with respect to the Australian National Maritime Museum Council fiasco. In that case the Minister, after receiving his new job, moved in almost straightaway and three senior members of the Council were notified that they were no longer required. I refer to Mr Alex Dix, Christine Klugman and Rear Admiral Andrew Robertson. They were removed from the Council. I understand that two of them received a call from the Minister's principal private secretary and that the Minister actually spoke to the Chairman, Mr Dix. Members of the Council said that the treatment of the three had been insulting and that the Government was `causing a wreck by its ineptitude'. They also said that the sacked administrators were the `most experienced in museum work'.

A point can be drawn from that when one looks at the articles of Film Australia. If the Minister is to give himself the power to appoint and dismiss at whim, perhaps those who are putting up their hands to volunteer should be a little wary, based on that incident with the Museum, which I think was extremely regrettable. Interestingly, in the telegram to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) protesting at these dismissals the sackings were described as `ham fisted' and it was pointed out that they would destabilise the Museum, which I think has only seven months to go before it opens in Darling Harbour. Interestingly, those who telegrammed the Prime Minister in those terms were continuing Council members-Professor Bolton, Mr Bruce Stannard and Mr John Evans. So I think the Minister may have trodden on a few toes in that respect.

A broader point is that, if the Minister is going to vest in himself the power to appoint and dismiss, he should provide some guarantees in his summing-up or at least say publicly that he will be reaching into the broader community and placing experts on these boards. The film industry needs the best available. The industry does not need a reaching down from the political process to put one's friends into place. Unfortunately, much as I personally respect him, the man appointed as the replacement for one of the dismissals from the Maritime Museum Council is Ken Wriedt, a former Labor Leader of the Government in the Senate and now an Opposition spokesman in Tasmania. I do not think that that appointment augurs well. Even though Mr Wriedt was a merchant mariner 40 years ago, he does not come to the position with any expertise. As I have said, if someone takes a job from this Government he should watch his step and make sure that he receives guarantees of some longevity in the appointment to make it worth while, otherwise he is likely to receive a telephone call to the effect that he has been dismissed.

A word of caution on Film Australia: the Government should not stack it with its mates. It should put capable and knowledgeable people in the positions. The film industry needs the best people available, not a lot of has-beens. If that is the case the Government will be doing well. We certainly do not want to see the likes of the former Minister who is now the back bench member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) turning up on a board such as this. My colleague in the Senate, Senator Puplick, the spokesman in this area, will also be making some comments about the proposed chairman of the Commission and whether or not there is, at least prima facie, a clash of interest there.

As I said, the Opposition supports the film industry. It has a proud record and the present and former governments can claim an active role in supporting it. It is interesting to note that the Age newspaper in an editorial in February said that the film industry, if prudently administered, could prove to be one of `inestimable benefit in projecting Australia to the world at large'. Indeed, it can, and we hope that the Minister for the Arts and Territories will approach his administration of the film industry in that vein.

Film Australia had sales to the value of $1.75m in 1986-87. So it has been quite successful, and this new entrepreneurial charter is a step in the right direction. There were several major productions last year. There was the major bicentennial film called Australia; there was a joint venture on Chinese technology, Roads to Xanadu; there was a co-production on social history entitled Willesee's Australians; and there was something that is dear to my heart-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation science project Last Chance for the Lucky Country, which was an excellent production. There was also a co-production on the environment called State of the World. Film Australia Pty Ltd has a broad charter and I understand that under the new arrangements it will be totally up to the company itself to determine what it is going to do.

The 50 projects on education and training for the departments last year netted in the vicinity of $3.47m. There has been a staff reduction from 133 to 106. I believe that Robin Hughes did a commendable job when she took over. I do not need to go back through the history of all of the problems that existed when she took over. We wish the organisation well. We want it to succeed. We will watch with interest the Minister's administration of this Government film unit with the view to ensuring that we avoid the types of headlines that we have seen in the past, such as `Film industry facing collapse, says Sam Neill', `Funding crisis hits Australian film industry' in the Australian Financial Review and `Film industry boom or bust' in the Australian of 16 May 1988.

There is concern in the community about the direction of the film industry. I would love the Minister to reply to me tonight but tomorrow night will do as long as there is some response to my concerns. I hope he will be able to answer the concerns that I have voiced in this second reading debate, in which, as I have said, the coalition joins with the Government in wishing the Bill a speedy passage. My colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) will be speaking in this debate. He was a spokesman in this area and I know that he had personal concerns about the future of the film industry. This will give him an opportunity, even though the debate has been guillotined, to make some comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Film Australia, the production division of the Australian Film Commission, is now to become Film Australia Pty Ltd, a wholly Commonwealth owned company. The Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) in his second reading speech made the point that, in one form or another, Film Australia has existed as the Commonwealth's film making body for three-quarters of a century. He spoke of its unique place in Australian cinematic history and of its innovation and technical excellence.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone here tonight-the Opposition and the Government-wishes the new Film Australia Pty Ltd the success and the unique place in Australia's history that the former Film Australia has had. I too will go back a little into the history of Film Australia to pay some small tribute to some of the greats of Film Australia. I am indebted to Judy Adamson, who supplied some of the information. Judy Adamson, who has worked with Film Australia for 20 years, has made a mark as a historian of the film industry in Australia.

The first film-maker to be employed by the Commonwealth Government was employed in 1911. His name was James Pinkerton Campbell. He was employed as a photographer-cinemaphotographer to film the building of Canberra. He was required to work out of his own home. He processed the film in his bath and the cost to the Government was his salary and his materials. This first employee was sacked after one year following a bureaucratic decision on the grounds that he was shooting too much film and did not understand how film worked. Despite this bureaucratic judgment, James Pinkerton Campbell's photographs and stills are well known to us all today. They are the pictures of early Canberra that we all treasure and boast of so much in this historic year.

In 1913 the then Government appointed Mr Bert Ive. I have with me a copy of a letter from the Department of External Affairs appointing him as a cinemaphotographer and photographer at a salary of #5 per week and a travelling allowance when absent from headquarters of 12s 6d per day with free rail, coach and steamer transit. Enclosed with the letter appointing him was an order for a railway ticket from Sydney to Melbourne with a sleeping berth. Bert Ive went on to become one of the greats of the silent era, as so many of the employees of the Commonwealth Film Unit went on to become the greats of Australian cinema.

Films were made and photographs taken for overseas migration publicity and for government departments, carefully costed against departments, with the bills paid on average six months or more after the filming. From 1925 to 1930 films were released each week successively by Paramount and MGM, and the money was remitted to Consolidated Revenue. The Commonwealth has always made money from Film Australia. The Australian National Film Board was set up in 1945 after 14 years of preparation and was disbanded in 1973 when the Department of the Media took over the Film Unit. It started at a eminent committee of individuals, including Ministers. It appointed a Producer-in-chief, who headed its Film Division.

In 1946 Stanley Hawes was employed. Yesterday Stanley Hawes handed over all his personal records to the National Film and Sound Archives. Stanley Hawes came from Britain, from the documentary movement, via the National Film Board of Canada. He was a contemporary of John Grierson, the man who invented documentaries. The British Crown Film Unit, as it was called, was abolished in the 1950s, much to Britain's regret today. Prior to World War II, 300 films were made for the Commonwealth Film Unit but when Stanley Hawes came the era of the greatest films began. I will list a few of them to remind honourable members of the great and proud history of Film Australia. In the 1940s there was the memorable film by John Heyer, The Valley is Ours. In the 1950s we had Maslyn Williams's New Guinea Patrol. In 1967 we had Ian Dunlop's award winning Desert People. In the 1970s there was a series Three to Go, including Peter Weir's Michael. That was the film that launched Peter Weir on his illustrious career. Another famous award winning film-indeed, an Academy Award winning film-was Bruce Petty's Leisure. Another famous film from Film Australia was Greg Reading's Counterplay. Another was Graham Chase's film, still shown everywhere today, Thirst.

Amongst the films that will last forever is the film history series, including The Passionate Industry by Joan Long. Another is The Australian Eye series, a history of Australian artists by David Muir. We also had the migrant experience series. Another film to bring great credit to Australia in the 1980s was Annie's Coming Out by Gill Brierly. A film already referred to by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) was Last Chance for the Lucky Country, a highly reviewed and outstandingly excellent film shown by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). In fact, it was the first time that a film that one could say was straight government propaganda for Australian trade was shown in prime time on a network slot, I think at 8 p.m. on the ABC.

Other films that have brought a great deal of enjoyment to the public are Graham Chase's Democracy, part of the yet to be released Real Life series; Hell Fire Pass about the Burma Railway, a brilliant film which was shown on Anzac Day this year; and Graham Chase's Cooee, part sponsored by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This film will be a feature documentary at the Sydney and Melbourne film festivals. Another film which has had rave reviews is Cane Toads, currently doing roaring business-a magnificent success for Film Australia.

The history of Film Australia in recent years has been assessed like this: in the 1940s films were made about national traditions and expansion. In the 1950s to 1960s there was an emphasis on Australia's potential as an exporter, for example, in mining. In the 1960s and 1970s Film Australia moved into social issues. I think that is where it has had its greatest success. It is a documentary film-maker. We have to ask what a documentary film is. A distinction should be made between featurettes and documentaries. A featurette is about places and processes; a documentary is about people. A documentary takes a routine subject and makes it interesting. Film Australia has taken countless routine subjects and made them fascinating. What is more, it has made artistic masterpieces.

As the new company begins, all of us who are grateful for the work of Film Australia will be expecting a very great deal. The employees of Film Australia have often worked with facilities, schedules and finance that the public simply does not associate with film-making, yet the public has come to enjoy countless numbers of the films of Film Australia. In the new company producers, directors, cinematographers and sound recordists will be employed under contract. We wish the new Board the good fortune to be able to choose its future direction as well as its future directors and producers, with an understanding of Film Australia's exceptional history so that Australians can continue to be as proud of the new company as we have been of Film Australia and, Madam Deputy Speaker, of its staff.

We are all confident that the new Board will not equate efficiency and excellence with mere staff reductions. We are all confident that market forces will allow that nothing can equate with the loyalty, the dedication and the extraordinary skills of the former employees of Film Australia, one of the Commonwealth Government's most successful units. Let us wish the new Board all success so that the end of Film Australia as it was is not the end of a great unit but the continuation of excellence in Australian film-making.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sam Goldwyn would have been proud to have been associated with Film Australia had he heard the speech of the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh). Certainly one does not want to detract from the achievements of Film Australia since 1911, when its predecessors were established. However, I must admit, given that the Federal Government has retrenched some of the employees of Film Australia, that some of the comments of the honourable member for Phillip about the dedication of the employees might not necessarily be reciprocated.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with great pleasure that I say just a few words on the Australian Film Commission Amendment Bill in the limited time available to me, particularly because in general terms I have a very high regard for the Australian Film industry-not just for the talents of the people in the industry, which I think are very great, but also for the contribution that the film industry has made to the promotion of the Australian national character, to the expression of the Australian personality and, I guess, to the creation and furtherance of a national consciousness. As a former diplomat, I have also seen the Australian Film industry's enormous achievements overseas in projecting Australia. That was long before the days of Crocodile Dundee and Crocodile Dundee II. Many wonderful films that went before did a great deal to promote the virtues of this country and to take away from the perceptions of foreigners the rather simplistic cliches that they believed about our country.

As others have pointed out, this legislation removes Film Australia from the clutches of the Australian Film Commission and establishes it as a wholly owned Commonwealth company along what the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) has described as commercial lines. I do not know how commercial we can call commercial lines when the Government is pumping $15m a year into it, but they are the words that the Minister has chosen to use. As other Opposition spokesmen have pointed out, not least the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), this seems a perfectly reasonable proposition. The Government is actually enacting legislation based on a statement by the former Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), when in May least year he put forward the proposals for streamlining Film Australia. The honourable member for Phillip might recall that that was the time the Government announced it was retrenching some of the employees of Film Australia.

To give the honourable member for Phillip credit, she gave a very interesting speech about the history of Film Australia, whose predecessor, as she pointed out, was established in 1911. The point of establishing its predecessor in 1911 was that effectively at that time Australia had no film industry at all. Honourable members will recall that in the 1930s we had an extraordinarily buoyant and dynamic film industry but going right back to 1911 there was nothing. The then Government established the predecessor to what is now Film Australia. We have now arrived in 1988, and 1911 is a long time ago-it was one year after my father was born. In 1988 we have our own flourishing film industry-or at least we did until 1987-which has been largely supported by the 10ba tax concessions.

We really need to look tonight at what Film Australia does and then ask ourselves whether it is really relevant in the context of our total film industry. If it is, we ought to be doing all we can to encourage it. If it is not, we ought to be looking at other ways of promoting the film industry. Film Australia has two basic functions. It has a departmental program, as it calls it, and it has a national program. The departmental program effectively makes documentaries and films for the Australian Government, such as films on behalf of Austrade to explain innovations in business and export industries in Australia; films for the former Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism on tourism and leisure in Australia; and a number of films to promote various social objectives of the Government-and I do not object to that-such as the film made for the drug campaign. It is interesting to note that the overflow of all this work has been passed on through subcontracting work to private film-makers because Film Australia has not been able to cope with the sheer volume of demand that has come from the public sector.

The second aspect of Film Australia's work is its national program. It has made a whole series of different kinds of films. As the honourable member for Phillip pointed out, some of these films have been of the highest quality. I think all of us have enjoyed watching those films from time to time. A curious feature of the national program when Film Australia was under the Australian Film Commission was that it employed a group of `leading Australians', as they were described in the Film Commission's annual report, to determine what sorts of films were to be made. That group of leading Australians put forward a number of ideas which led to the people working in what is now Film Australia deciding what to make in 1987-88 and 1988-89. Some of the highlights have been mentioned by other speakers. Its made Last Chance for a Lucky Country, Roads to Xanadu, Willesee's Australians and so on. Some of these films have done very well and have been well promoted not just in cinemas but through television as well.

The national program function is basically, however, a commercial function. It is a commercial function which has really been determined by what we could describe as a sort of Council of the Great. They have put forward the recommendations for what should be done. As somebody who comes from a political party which is not paternalistic, that strikes me as being probably a rather curious way of making a decision on what sorts of films should be made. I often think that ordinary people ought to be consulted and considered when taxpayers' money is being spent, not just a few people who are in government or within a bureaucracy and who happen to think a particular film would be appropriate. However, let us not go into that philosophical debate.

The question we have to ask ourselves, as I mentioned earlier, is how Film Australia, under the new structure that the previous Minister really determined, will work. I do not think, frankly, we can give credit to the present Minister; I think we have to give credit to the honourable member for Robertson. This decision was announced, if I recall correctly, in the May statement last year. So, let us not forget the role of the honourable member for Robertson in this matter and let us not give credit to the new Minister. The question is: is this terribly relevant to the way the Government and Australia should see the future of the film industry? Therefore, we need to look at the industry in its total context.

At the moment, for one reason or another-and I do not blame the present Government for this-we have a bit of a hotch potch in our film industry. The Australian Film Commission has lost its film making functions to the new Film Australia company. We have the 10ba tax concession which is just lingering on. I happen to be totally convinced that the present Minister simply will buy the proposals which are put to him by the Australian Film Commission, by Kim Williams and Phillip Adams. I bet any money that the Minister will buy their proposal and set up a film bank. If that is done, they will have Film Australia, their film bank and the Film Commission. Probably what we will lose are the very progressive and imaginative tax concessions under 10ba which were introduced by the Fraser Government. The Minister ought to reconsider the importance of those tax concessions and not be too captured by the bureaucrats in the Australian Film Commission. I have had some dealings with it over the years. I ask the Minister not to be too captured by it, but to try to think about what the alternatives may be.

The 10ba tax concession has been a fantastic success. There is no question of that. I do not think anybody would argue with that. There have been problems. There have been questions about whether some people have been investing in the industry just to minimise their tax burden. That surely is true. There is no question about that. The fact is that 10ba set the whole of the Australian film industry on fire. It was a wonderful success. I question why the Government is so enthusiastic to cut out 10ba and simply to have Film Australia and this new film bank that it will definitely set up.

The film bank proposal is an extremely paternalistic one. There will be Phillip Adams with his lovely radio program in the mornings, his newspaper articles, his showmanship and his deliberately chosen black clothes with his passion for the Australian Labor Party worn on his sleeve. There he will be with his friend Kim Williams, who played such a political role in the last Federal election, ultimately deciding with a few people what films Australia should make, and how that will differ from the present 10ba arrangement. Although the Minister has discretion as to whether 10ba should apply to a certain project, the reality is that the 10ba proposal is a proposal whereby ordinary people in the film industry-the producers, the financiers and so on-make the decision whether the project should go ahead. They have to make that decision taking into consideration what the ordinary Australian and the overseas audience are likely to want. I am sorry that the Government will go for the old film bank proposal and that it will abandon 10ba or any kind of tax concession as a form of assistance for the film industry altogether.

As far as Film Australia is concerned, which is what I really should be talking about, I do not think the Government should be walking away-and dare I say this to the Government at this time-from the proposal that it should be considering the future of Film Australia in the context of privatising it. After all, as far as the Government work is concerned, the departmental program, as Film Australia calls it, could very easily be contracted out to private film makers in this country. On the other hand, I would not like to see many of the other productive elements of the national program, as it is called, abandoned altogether. But, if Film Australia were a private company and if the Government were to have the vision to continue with the tax concessions that the Fraser Government provided to the industry to revive and to make that industry dynamic, I think Film Australia would be able to pursue what is now called its national program very effectively and very creatively.

In conclusion, let me reiterate what I said at the beginning. We are blessed with a wonderful film industry and we, as members of this Parliament, will want to do all we can to ensure that that film industry continues to prosper. I very much hope that the Minister in his deliberations on the Australian Film Commission's proposals for a film bank does not fall for the demands of the bureaucrats but will use the sort of vision that was seen in the actions of the Fraser Government to ensure that our industry thrives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am using the adjournment debate in lieu of Question Time to ask a question of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West). The Torrens Road Drainage Authority (TRDA) comprises the Hindmarsh, Enfield, Woodville and Port Adelaide councils and is responsible for the safe disposal of storm and waste water from a 1,600- hectare catchment which is populated by some 200,000 residents. In 1972, acting on an undertaking on the part of the then Minister for Local Government, the Torrens Road Drainage Authority committed itself to a capital expenditure program in excess of $8m. The Commonwealth undertook to grant an easement over wetlands in what is known as the `overshoot' area at the rear of the Dean Rifle Range, an area which obviously cannot be used for commercial, residential or recreational purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: For 16 years, the TRDA has been developing a stormwater run-off system on the understanding that it would be given effective control over that system. The Authority has developed two ponding basins on tidal swamp land near the Port River to collect storm and waste water before letting it run out to the tidal North Arm Creek and the Magazine Creek. In 1985, the Authority's ponding system was put to the acid test when a deadly spill of copper chromium arsenate found its way into the drainage system. Thanks to the existence of the ponding basin, the pollutant was prevented from flowing out into the tidal system. The ponding system is adjacent to the finely balanced mangrove ecosystem described by two separate authorities as an essential nursery for South Australia's fishing industry. The loss of the mangrove swamps would have been irreplaceable and the loss to South Australia's fishing industry would have run into millions.

Following the chemical spill, the Harbison report stated that the ponding basin system played a decisive role in averting a disaster and must remain. The Commonwealth, after 16 years, has now reneged on its undertaking to grant an easement over the area in question. It has backed out of the agreement which was the cornerstone of the Torrens Road Drainage Authority's $8m investment program. The Federal Government has gone back on its word because it is offering the land in question for sale by public tender-land that has been described by experts as unsuitable for any use other than the dispersal of stormwater. Yet an officer of the Australian Property Group, acting on behalf of the Hawke Labor Government, has dared to cast aspersions on the principles of the TRDA. I quote:
I must express my extreme disappointment at the evident lack of professionalism and ethics displayed by your organisation, which has seriously misinformed and misled.

The indications are that there are two key players in the sale by tender: the Adelaide City Council, for its long term refuse disposal-it is easy to tax refuse, but how does one tax stormwater?-and the State Government which could well bid to establish an industrial complex or even a residential development. That would be good-dead flat with no schools, no shops, no trees, no sewerage and no public transport. It would not matter if one forgot to put out one's bins on rubbish night; one could just take them over to the Wingfield dump. The renowned Dean Rifle Range regulars have been enjoying their sport on weekends for more than 60 years. To build anything on the land would require the deposit of some two million cubic metres of fill. And then, having filled it, where would the stormwater go? Obviously, it would have to be diverted, adding millions to the Torrens Road Drainage Authority's already large investment.

To cap it all, in 1986 the then Minister for local government asked the TRDA to pay $2m for the land. When the Authority protested, the Minister-this is on record-suggested the use of the South Australian Valuer-General as an independent arbitrator. However, the Minister must have made some inquiries as, within days of his suggestion, his Private Secretary wrote to the Authority disclaiming any agreement to be bound by the Auditor-General's valuation. That was a timely move because the Auditor-General valued the property at $120,000-a far cry from the Minister's $2m asking price. On the other hand, the Hawke Labor Government has put the property to tender and intends to sell it to the highest bidder, despite the fact that a caveat has been placed on the block to preclude any future use other than the dispersal of stormwater. There are 320 hectares up for sale. The TRDA is prepared to pay a fair price for a minimum requirement of 45 hectares. If that is the way the Hawke Labor Government expects to treat local government, why should the Australian people vote for the Hawke Government's referendum proposal on local government?

In summary, we are talking about the foresight and initiative of the Torrens Road Drainage Authority which has successfully controlled flood and stormwaters. The South Australian Department of Marine and Harbors has constructed a levee bank system that is an integral part of the protection of the mangrove ecosystem. We have had three struggling statements from the former Minister, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), the former member for Port Adelaide and the former member for Adelaide. It is called a flick pass. Where is the Australian Labor Party on this issue? The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) is quick to jump on the yellowcake trail, but he has missed the floodwaters in his constituents' backyard. Perhaps the new honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) will join me in taking up the cudgels on behalf of our constituents.

I rise to inform the House of events in my electorate last week which saw the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) having to defend himself against mischievous allegations by the Northern Territory Treasurer. SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we should be charitable in this case and assume that the Northern Territory Treasurer thought that the rorts that have become commonplace and are acknowledged as being so in the Northern Territory are also carried out by the Federal Government. Let us remind the Northern Territory Government that this Government will not tolerate those sorts of activities. That is not the fault of the Federal Government; it is the fault of the inappropriate and incapable management of the Northern Territory Government. The Northern Territory Chief Minister has the temerity to say that the reality is that we live in difficult economic times; the business community throughout this country is unimpressed with government. Let us hear what he has to say about the accolades that this Federal Labor Government has received from the business sector. We all know what they have been. TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of parliament, and as an ordinary citizen, matters often come before me which engender a sense of outrage or injustice, but sometimes that injustice seems so nonsensical that I despair for my fellow Australians who do not possess the wit to recognise when honest citizens are being held to ransom on the pretence that they are being protected from evil. All honourable members would have, at some time, dealt with constituents anxious to elicit our assistance to obtain an Australian passport-some of them for the first time. Maybe they have not travelled out of Australia before, or maybe they have newly acquired the status of an Australian citizen thereby sharing the privileges and responsibilities attaching to being an Australian in the full sense of the word.

SPEECH.PARA: But in recent years, with the advent of the responsible Minister's changes to proof of identity, I am often confronted with the wrath and anguish of a person who has lived in this country for sometimes near on 60 years, reared all his or her children as Australians, served under the Australian flag during a world war and is now being treated as a foreigner in his own country. That person may have held as many as three or four previous Australian passports, but the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) refuses to acknowledge that that person is Australian without that person first proving to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that he or she lived in Australia between 1944 and 1949. Fine, honourable members might say, there is no problem with that. That person could show the Department his bank books, school certificates and electoral enrolment cards for that period. I ask honourable members whether they have kept their personal papers for the past 40 years. I ask whether honourable members would in moving home, perhaps from one State to another, sometimes every few years, diligently pack up all those bits and pieces they no longer feel vital to their continuing activities? Of course they would not. How does such a person prove that he was here? Perhaps if that person were a parent, a child may have been born in that period. However, that alone is not enough. Possibly that person may have kept in touch with a friend of longstanding. Let us hope so because at least such a friend could vouch for him.

What I am getting at is that the Minister in his quest to protect us from those people who have a desire to deceive in respect of their identities has caught in his trap many ordinary Australians who have not thought of themselves as anything but Australian for the major part of their lives. These people consider it a personal affront to have doubt cast on their status by some clerk or public servant endeavouring to administer procedures instituted by a Minister far removed from the front counter. The Minister has substantial discretion under the regulations of the Passports Act 1938. Surely the Minister could exercise that discretion in cases where it is obvious that he is not dealing with some sinister criminal wishing to obtain a passport for nefarious purposes.

I am the first to acknowledge that more often than not we can become confused as to what is our legitimate entitlement. Some of us believe that the rules are made for the man down the street; certainly not ourselves. When the Government, in the course of protecting us from ourselves, introduces measures which so obviously cause unnecessary anguish, not to mention financial strain, then it is time the Government took another look at who is benefiting from such moves. Certainly it is not the ordinary Australian who placed his faith in the Government by electing it to office. He can see only that a slur has been cast on his character by the fact that, despite all the evidence he can provide that he has been a loyal Australian for the major part of his life, he must suffer the indignity of having a clerk dismiss this out of hand because it does not fit in with a set of inflexible procedures which do not allow for human judgment to be made. Perhaps the Minister can offer a humane solution to this most human problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that this will be one of the last speeches I shall make in this chamber. Most certainly it will be my last speech on the adjournment. In this chamber, full of character and traditions, it is appropriate this evening that I pay tribute to someone who was a great believer in traditions. Last Saturday the Illawarra region bade farewell to one of the real characters of that area, Miss Ethel Hayton. She helped many people throughout her long life time and she worked with all the local media.

SPEECH.PARA: Miss Hayton came to the Illawarra region with her parents as a young person. Her father died soon after. She devoted the 75 years of her life to helping the people there. I think this was reflected in her funeral service, at which we had representatives of all the religions in the region. We had representatives of the whole community, from the trade unions through to academics, all paying tribute to a person who had devoted her life to helping others. I had a special affection for her. I do not think that she was of the same political persuasion as I. A few years back she became a Member of the Order of the British Empire. As someone who is very keen on Australian honours, not Imperial honours, I wrote to her and said that although I was opposed to Imperial honours I felt that there was no-one who was more deserving of this Imperial honour than Miss Ethel Hayton, who had a great affection for the British royal family. I think the degree of respect in which she was held in the community was reflected in the large attendance at her funeral service at the cathedral in Wollongong last Saturday.

I quote now from the speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) of 22 May 1986 when he pointed out:

In my view the Joint Parliamentary Committee's main task would be to ensure that any surveillance or investigation of the activities of Australian citizens by ASIO was carried out properly and with due consideration of the civil rights of such citizens. The 1986-87 ASIO report to the Parliament has included, in its comments on its activities during the year, the comment that `around fifty foreign officials in Australia have an undeclared intelligence role, or are otherwise engaged in acts of foreign interference'. Who will have access to this kind of information? Members, the staff, the staff of some members of the committee, no doubt, and the reporting staff.
