TALK.START.PARA: —After having spent 16 years in this House, and this perhaps being the last opportunity I will have to speak in this provisional Parliament House, I raise the one issue that has been the most traumatic faced by my constituents during the last 58 years, an issue that has placed deep scars on the farming community, the business community and the rural work force. The rural crisis in the Mallee and Wimmera regions of my electorate reflected, of course, a series of seasonal disasters as well as economic problems confronting agriculture generally.

SPEECH.PARA: There is significant variation in the financial circumstances of primary producers in my region. The variation is a product of many factors, including whether land was purchased in the late 1970s or the early 1980s. Timing has always been an important factor. It would often be the case that a younger farmer who has taken over a farm would be in a better position than perhaps an older farmer who has recently bought more land in order to be able to provide living areas for his children. Approximately 1,500 primary producers were placed in a critical situation in my electorate and yet, during this most significant crisis, the Federal Government massively increased interest rates and fuel prices and introduced an assets test on pensions and unemployment benefits, and is now poised perhaps to introduce an assets test on Austudy.

What has been the result of these policies Australia-wide? What rewards did country people get in their time of crisis, great as their contribution has been to export earnings? An analysis of the 1986 census data tells us that family incomes in large regions of rural Australia are but half of those in metropolitan areas. The highest proportion of families on incomes below $12,000 are today in rural regions of Australia. If one looks at the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, which is now 14 years old, one sees that rural impoverishment was extensive, with one-quarter of country Australians in poverty compared to one-sixth of city people. This situation has worsened, and there is no doubt that the most underprivileged people today are in the country. Both the magnitude and the extent of the problem are worse. This, sadly, is not an election issue. To this Government it is out of sight and out of mind, and proud rural people simply do not make a fuss. They either refuse social welfare handouts or find that government policies exclude them from eligibility. I hope that in the May economic statement, to come into this Parliament tomorrow, no further penalties will be imposed on rural Australians, who earn 40 per cent of our export income.

Our social structures in rural regions and our safety nets of volunteer help networks for which we were renowned are today breaking down. We are seeing a rapidly increasing proportion of the aged, with young people leaving our districts. Paradoxically, many people are also retiring from and quitting the cities in order to have a cheaper and more satisfying rural lifestyle. At a time when we need more services, particularly in the health, welfare, transport and communications areas, such services are under pressure and are being either rationalised or regionalised. Medicare has almost totally destroyed the bush nursing hospital system in Victoria, with people unable to pay both the Medicare levy and private insurance bypassing local hospitals to attend public hospitals hundreds of kilometres away.

These pressures are also on our schools and our sporting clubs and are affecting the social outlets of our people. As usual, innovation, rapid diversity, and the capacity to meet a crisis head on and to respond under extreme economic and social pressures will ensure that our region has a future, but the tragedy has been that this Government has allowed so many people to suffer unnecessarily through this very difficult period.

The Council also intends to construct a teahouse in the lower hall of the Broadmeadows Town Hall. This is part of the sister city relationship that Broadmeadows has with the city of Nagareyama in Japan.

There is no progress in hate.

The father of the House, with the experience he had during the Second World War, has some credibility in making statements on these matters. Our efforts now are best directed to developing peaceful, mutually beneficial relations with Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago the nation celebrated Mothers Day and in September we will recognise Fathers Day. Mothering Sunday has long been observed among the churches, but modern Mothers Day as we know it was established in the United States of America following a campaign by one Anna Jarvis. Official recognition was given in 1914 when President Woodrow Wilson signed a joint resolution of Congress for government observance of Mothers Day. Likewise, Fathers Day was the idea of another American, a Sonora Dodd in 1909. Fathers Day became official when, again, Woodrow Wilson approved it in 1916. These days are observed in Australia to honour our parents and to reflect on family relationships. But, regrettably, the commercial aspect has largely overtaken the spiritual side of the original intention.

SPEECH.PARA: But what about Children's Day? This is a question that has been asked by 11-year-old Kylie Ives of Mount Evelyn, in my electorate. She, like Anna Jarvis and Sonora Dodd, wants to set up a special day. Kylie wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and said:
I am writing to you on behalf of my sisters Tammy, Teresa, my fellow students of MDA Grammar School, also I believe all the children in Australia.
She requested the Prime Minister to `recognise on a set day of the year, preferably Sunday, 23rd October 1988, a day known to the community as ``Children's Day'' '. The letter continued:
We believe we are important young Australians warranting a day of recognition, equivalent to our parents.
We as children no longer wish to be seen and not heard, but seen, recognised, and heard, through our request for `Children's Day'.

She also wrote to the Premier, Mr Cain; the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria; and her own shire, the Shire of Lilydale, which approved of and supported her idea. She wrote to the State members of parliament who share the area of our neighbourhood, and they, too, supported her. She also wrote to the Australian Bicentennial Authority, which replied:

Children's Week occurs in the last week of October, and Universal Children's Day is celebrated on the fourth Wednesday of October each year. UNICEF notes this special day internationally in many countries, including Australia.
She also wrote to the Archbishop of Melbourne and Archdeacon Alan Nichols replied:

While recognising the value of the sentiments you have expressed about the need for children to be affirmed and recognised in Australian society, there are at present a number of efforts in this direction at present, and would be a pity to in any way duplicate them. In particular, there is a Children's Week sponsored by the Children's Welfare Association of Victoria, and linked now with a National Children's Week, held in October each year. This is a significant effort now at not only recognising children in welfare, but affirming children in our society in a much broader way. The Anglican welfare agencies and other groups are strongly supporting this endeavour.
She attached other letters from children who supported her idea and they said things like this:
Children are important too.
Without children there would be nobody.
Everyone or nearly everyone thinks that kids are servants.
We kids are the future.

So Kylie Ives wants to see a children's day gazetted in the Australian calendar. Her argument is simply that children should be given fair recognition of their rights and obligations. Some countries, such as Korea, have a public holiday for children's day. Japan sets aside 5 May to honour all children of the country and to wish them happiness and 17 May as a children's protection day. Children's day is celebrated in the United States of America. The Bicentennial is an ideal time for the Government to take a national approach. I urge the Prime Minister to adopt this idea and put children's day on a more official footing, perhaps coinciding with the United Nations Children's Fund children's day. It will give yet another focus to the Government's important pledge that no child need live in poverty by 1990.

That is a curious argument because, after all, in South Australia those very same residents receive State Government concessions for water rates and council rates, and the council rates are paid in exactly the same way as the PABX telephone bills. They also receive concessions for drivers licences, motor vehicle registrations, electricity-which, it should be remembered, goes to the home and is then divided amongst the units-St John Ambulance membership, travel, and so on.

I think it is a gross injustice that the Minister for Social Security does not provide this concession to pensioners who live in these circumstances, particularly at the Victor Harbor Lutheran Home. I call on the Government to take note of the new technology, realise that retired people are increasingly living under these sorts of arrangements and make sure that they can obtain concessions. Surely the Government and members opposite do not want to deny concessions to these people I would not have thought so. If that is the case, I would expect the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, and the backbenchers behind him to take up this issue and ensure that the Minister for Social Security does the right thing by the retired people who live under these sorts of arrangements and give the people of the Victor Harbor Lutheran Home and others in those circumstances in my electorate the opportunity to obtain the concessions that are available to others.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your discrimination in calling me. Government members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe I am throwing bouquets, but it is the third last night that we are here, so let us be kind and gentle. The Australian Pavilion is an absolute fizzler. While I am on the subject, why did we not have the Queensland people who were responsible for the opening of Expo come down here and handle the opening of Parliament House? At the opening of Parliament House we had all the grandeur, the fanfare, the glitter and the glamour inside the House. TALK.START.PARA: —In the minute that is left to me tonight I wish to speak on the question of public liability insurance. It is an issue that faces a large number of voluntary organisations such as surf clubs, Apex, Rotary and Lions clubs, and bushfire brigades. I have been approached by representatives of the Soldiers Beach and the Lakes Beach surf clubs in my electorate. They are very concerned about the cost of public liability insurance. At the moment the Soldiers Beach surf club has to pay out more than $2,000 to the national surf lifesaving movement for public liability insurance. That is the result of people in our society being more prepared to sue. It is something which the former New South Wales Government sought to rectify with Workcover and Transcover. Something has to be done about surf clubs to make sure that they are not bankrupted by the ever-increasing cost of public liability insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall go into a little more detail as to why this is such an important issue for surf clubs. Last Saturday evening I had the honour of being present at the annual presentation night for the Soldiers Beach surf life saving club. As the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), who is in the House at the moment, would be aware, Soldiers Beach is one of the premier surfing beaches on Australia's east coast. The President of that surf club, John Edwards, and the Secretary of the Lakes Beach surf life saving club, Judy Waldron, have approached me about this very important issue. I understand that the Brunswick Heads surf life saving club has written to most of the surf life saving clubs in New South Wales, suggesting that there be some combined action by clubs to make sure that they are not financially crippled by the ever-increasing cost of public liability insurance.

Not only is the cost of the insurance premiums high, but also the officers of surf life saving clubs are concerned that, if there is a serious accident at one of the beaches which they patrol and someone successfully argues in court that one of the members of the club has failed to carry out his duty properly, the club could be sued and lose all of its assets and that, if the payment to the injured party cannot be met by the club's assets, the officers of the club could forfeit their own personal assets.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should incorporate.

—As the honourable member suggests, surf life saving clubs should incorporate to make sure that their liability is limited; but that costs a great deal of money and many surf life saving clubs are not aware that they should carry out that sensible action.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the national surf life saving movement for organising an insurance policy which covers most of the clubs. As I said, it is not cheap. It costs the Soldiers Beach surf life saving club $2,000 to hold that insurance. I understand also that there is some doubt amongst the clubs as to what exactly is covered. I think that has to be finalised. Given the hour, I conclude simply by saying how important this matter is. I hope that the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia will try to make sure that most of the amount of more than $1m that this Government provides for the clubs, thanks to the efforts of the honourable member for Parramatta over many years, will be used to provide grants for equipment to the local clubs and to provide sensible things such as public liability insurance.
